activities.description: The breathtaking natural beauty of Colorado's largest glacial lakes, reflecting some of the nation's highest peaks, makes Twin Lakes one of the world's most scenic places. This 12 mile loop trail circles these stunning alpine lakes, and highlights the beautiful scenery the surrounds the area. Enjoy the view of Mt. Elbert, the highest peak in Colorado, from the trail.  This is a multi-use trail, so please share the path.

places.name: CDT CO28: Gold Hill to Georgia Pass
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO28: Gold Hill to Georgia Pass
activities.description: The CDT runs for 19.7 miles from Gold Hill Trailhead on Hwy 9 to Georgia Pass. Along the way the trail passes Brewery Hill and Mount Guyot.

places.name: Tipperary Creek Loop
places.directions: From Denver travel west on I-70and take exit 232 onto Highway 40 west.  Pass through Winter Park and into Fraser.  Turn left at the light by the Fraser Valley Center.  This is Elk Creek Road.  Park in the Fraser Valley Center.

activities.name: Tipperary Creek Loop
activities.description: Tipperary Creek trail is a 20 mile loop near the city of Fraser, CO. This is a winding singletrack, with some doubletrack and fireroads mixed in, that will you through forests and out into open fields where you can take in the stunning scenery around you. This trail is mainly used for mountain biking, so be careful and make sure you share the path!

places.name: CDT CO43: North Lake to Wyoming Border
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO43: North Lake to Wyoming Border
activities.description: The CDT in Colorado runs just under 25 miles from North Lake to the Wyoming Border. Along the way, the trail passes Little Agnes Mountain, Dome Peak, Buck Mountain South, Buck Mountain North, and Black Mountain. To continue reading the trail descriptions to the north, please pick up the trail listings in Wyoming.

places.name: Barney Ford To Moonstone
places.directions: From Breckinridge take Boreas pass road up the mountain till you get to baldy road and turn left.  Once on Baldy road turn left on sally barber for couple hundred yards and you will see a pole with small signs on it at the Barney Ford trail head.  Once on the trail make sure you follow the arrow that points to the right.  Take this trail down till you will cross a road and it will turn into the moonstone trail.

activities.name: Barney Ford To Moonstone
activities.description: Barney Ford To Moonstone actually follows 3 trails: Carter Park, Moonstone, and Barney Ford. Most of the trail follows along an old mine trail with plenty of mine ruins to keep you interested. The hike is a fairly gentle hike that winds through the beautiful forest.

places.name: East Boulder Trail
places.directions: From 95th Street (Hover in Longmont), go south to Valmont Road. Turn west on Valmont, and less than 1 mile there will be a parking lot on the south side of Valmont.  Or, go south further to Arapahoe,  Turn west on Arapahoe and go about 2 miles to a dirt road with a sign for Teller Farms on the north side.  Turn north and the parking lot just up the road.

activities.name: East Boulder Trail
activities.description: Hike on this flat path through open meadows and around a pristine lake. This is an easy trail, perfect for families with children, or great just for stretching the legs. You'll encounter joggers and mountain bikers along here, so please practice trail etiquette!

places.name: CDT CO21: Garden Basin to Cottonwood Pass Road
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO21: Garden Basin to Cottonwood Pass Road
activities.description: Section 21 of the CDT in Colorado runs 10.3 miles from the Garden Basin Trailhead to the trailhead on Cottonwood Pass Road. Along the way, the trail passes Mount Kreutzer, Chalk Rock Mountain, Sanford Creek, Cow Creek, the headwaters of the Taylor River, Jones Mountain, and Jones Mountain North.

places.name: Indian Creek Loop
places.directions: Wadsworth Blvd south of C470 for about 3 miles.  Waterton Rd is on the left, with parking lot located about 100 yards from the intersection.

activities.name: Indian Creek Loop
activities.description: Hike through lush forests and open fields that look out on the surrounding Front Country. Most of this trail is on natural surfaces, however there is a section that you'll be hiking on gravel. This is a fairly difficult trail that winds up the mountain and climbs along the ridgeline. This is a multi-use trail, and a popular mountain bike trail, so please share the path and practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Poplar Gulch
places.directions: This trail can be started either in the ghost town of St. Elmo or from the north off of CR344.

activities.name: Poplar Gulch
activities.description: From the ghost town of St. Elmo at 10,000 ft., this trail climbs to 12,250ft. at a pass then descends to CR344 leading down to Cottonwood Lake.

places.name: Meadow Mountain
places.directions: Exit I-70 on exit 171 and get on Highway 24 heading towards Minturn.  Enter the Ranger Station on the right side of the road and park in the parking lot.

activities.name: Meadow Mountain
activities.description: This trail is an old forest road and climbs gradually through large open meadows, with relics of old cabins and corrals, and some aspen and spruce-fir forest near the top.  The line shack is a small cabin that lies at the end of the trail. The line shack offers a good place for lunch and a vantage point of some views of the Gore Range and Beaver Creek ski area. Evidence of old ski runs shows that this was once an old ski area.

places.name: Hewlett Gulch
places.directions: Go north out of Fort Collins on Hwy 287. Take a left at the Poudre Canyon turnoff (Ted's Place). From Ted's Place, go 10 miles up the canyon. Trail is on north side of the road between mile markers 112 &amp; 111 just after the small town of Poudre Park. There is no designated parking lot, so find a safe place at the side of the road to park. Trail is on other end of a bridge that crosses the river.

activities.name: Hewlett Gulch
activities.description: The trail leads north following an old road along Gordon Creek past foundations remaining from homesteads established between 1911 and 1925. At the two mile mark there is a fork in the trail. The main trail continues north and winds through a narrow canyon with many stream crossings before heading uphill out of the creek drainage into a meadow.  To the left a steep and un-maintained trail is visible. This non-system route leaves the stream and eventually loops back to connect with the trail. Hewlett Gulch trailhead accommodates approximately 22 vehicles.

places.name: Edna Mae Bennett Nature Trail
places.directions: Head for the Paseo entrance to Palmer Park and park at the trailhead right at that entrance (Paseo and Chelton.)  The trail is off to the north of the restrooms.

activities.name: Edna Mae Bennet Nature Trail
activities.description: Edna Mae Bennet is a 3/4 mile loop (the city of Colorado Springs says .75 mile, the Palmer Park trail guide says 2.6 miles, but it felt more like 3/4 of a mile when I hiked it) rated advanced, or black by the park's green/blue/black rating system.  It's got lots of technical steps (both stone and wood) and lots of drop offs and is very rocky.  It's also got some beautiful scenery and lots of bunny rabbits and squirrels to check out (that's the only wildlife I saw, although I don't doubt that there are other species lurking,) and it takes you down into the north canon, away from the roads and picnic areas.  It also intersects with the Templeton Trail if you want to get in more mileage.  All in all, a really cool, albeit short, hike.

places.name: Serpent's Trail
places.directions: From Grand Junction take Grand Ave/Hwy 340 across the Colorado River and turn left onto Monument Road.  Follow the road as it curves around and continue to the east entrance of the Colorado National Monument.  Shortly after entering the Monument a parking area for "Devil's Kitchen" will appear on your left.  Park here.  Serpent's Trail begins just across the road from the parking area. Parking is also available on the right, just before this, at the Devil's Kitchen picnic area.

activities.name: Serpent's Trail
activities.description: Serpent's trail is a historic trail; it was once used as the main way to access the higher areas of the Monument before Rim Rock Drive was built.  It is an out-and-back trail comprised of over 50 switchbacks.  The views from the trail are outstanding and so is the work that was done to the trail to make it passable.

places.name: Flume Loop
places.directions: Drive to Breckenridge via hwy 9.  Parking lot is just west of Hwy 9 on Valley Brook Rd.  Ride across Hwy 9, up Highlands Drive about a 100 yds and look for the lower Flume trail sign on both sides of the street.

activities.name: Flume Loop
activities.description: There are 3 loop trails that run north to south: the lower, middle, and upper flume. On these trails you'll find rocky paths running through thick forests. Every once in a while you'll come to a meadow where the forests breaks a little, and you can get beautiful views of the surrounding area. This trail is not that secluded and you can usually see homes from it.  This trail is multi-use so please share the trail with mountain bikers.

places.name: CDT CO09: Beartown Trailhead to Stony Pass Trailhead
places.directions: See Google Maps location given.

activities.name: CDT CO09: Beartown Trailhead to Stony Pass Trailhead
activities.description: Section 9 of the Continental Divide Trail runs 7.7 miles from the Beartown Trailhead to the Stony Pass Trailhead. 1.4 miles after leaving the Beartown Trailhead the CDT joins up with the Colorado Trail and runs concurrent with it. Along the way, the trail passes Bear Creek, Beartown Bald, and Stony Pass Peak.

places.name: CDT CO17: Sargents Mesa to Marshall Pass
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO17: Sargents Mesa to Marshall Pass
activities.description: The CDT runs for 14.5 miles from Sargents Mesa to Marshall Pass. Along the way the trail passes Windy Peak and Headwaters Hill.

places.name: Smuggler Road
places.directions: If you are coming off Independence Pass going West, turn right on Park Avenue.  Continue down on this road, it turns into Park Circle.  Slide right onto Co Rd 20/Smuggler Mountain Road.  Take a right after a couple hundred feet and you will be at the dirt parking lot at the base of the trail.

activities.name: Smuggler Road
activities.description: Smuggler Road takes you up a quick and easy trail to the the top of Smuggler Mountain. From the top you'll be able to take in the beautiful views of the surrounding area. You get all the views with less of the work!

places.name: Sand Canyon Trail
places.directions: Southwest of Cortez, up McElmo Canyon to signed trailhead, about 15 miles west of Cortez. Spring or autumn best times, but I rode it in mid-summer at sunup. 6000'

activities.name: Sand Canyon Trail
activities.description: Sand Canyon contains many Ancestral Puebloan archaeological sites. The popular Sand Canyon Trail is 6.5 miles (one-way) from Sand Canyon Pueblo down to the lower trailhead in McElmo Canyon.

places.name: Coyote Ridge
places.directions: From Fort Collins, get onto Taft Hill Rd heading south towards Loveland, once you pass the land fill on your right go another 1.5/2 miles till you see the parking lot on the right hand side.From Loveland, get onto Taft Hill Rd heading North, if you pass the Fort Collins land fill you have gone to far, turn around and follow the directions above.

activities.name: Coyote Ridge
activities.description: Coyote ridge is a nice trail that is easy to access from Fort Collins and Loveland. It offers some great views of the front range and the plains and is fairly rocky in spots.

places.name: Midland Railroad Trail
places.directions: H24 up the pass, past Manitou, u-turn back down the pass at the Waldo Canyon trail head parking lot, pull off into the median about 1/2 mile down.

activities.name: Midland Railroad Trail
activities.description: aka Abandoned Train Tunnels The western trail head is difficult to see when coming down the highway, and the median pull off can come up on you quickly so stay in the left lane.  There will be other cars/hikers on this route whenever its nice out, so if watching for them it will be easy to figure out.  The path starts near the guardrail on the other side, so time your dash across the highway carefully especially if you have kids.   The trail is washed out in a handful of spots, but this is still a very kid friendly trek.  There are five open tunnels, only one of which is really long enough to require a flash light.  (Note that the area can also be accessed from the waterfall near the end of Manitou off a social trail, so the numbering of the tunnels in order to describe location is somewhat relative.) There is a sixth tunnel (on the Manitou side) that has a no trespassing sign, but was not blocked.  Easily recognizable as it is the only tunnel with wooden girders, and it appeared to be cut through clay instead of granite like the others.  It also looks long enough to need a light source or bends just enough to obscure the other side.

places.name: James Peak
places.directions: From Idaho Springs take I-70 west to US 40 over Berthoud Pass to FS 128 take second right after mile marker 234 and park anywhere on the side of the dirt road.

activities.name: James Peak
activities.description: James Peak Trail is an incredibly scenic trail that leads up the mountain providing stunning views. The trail starts out traversing the popular St. Marys Glacier, a permanent ice field at the base of the mountain. Crossing the glacier the trail leads out into an open meadow where you are able to lay your eyes on the beautiful profile of James Peak.  Summit either by switchbacks or a direct, uphill trail, either way you'll get to the top and be able to enjoy amazing mountaintop views! Take skis or a snowboard in the winter and enjoy some backcountry skiing as well!

places.name: Strand Hill
places.directions: Take highway 135 for 2 miles south out of town and turn onto Brush Creek Road on the left. Park in one of the parking spots (psuedo-trailheads) and ride your bike down the dirt road until you get to a jeep road on the right. You have to follow that up several climbs and go pretty far until you actually get to Strand Hill Trail. It's pretty hard to find if you're not a local.

activities.name: Strand Hill
activities.description: The Strand Hill loop contains some old, steep gravel roads, but if you jump on one of the other nearby trails (Strand Bonus Trail or the Canal Trail) you can access the Strand Hill trail and the top of Strand Hill via singletrack in an out-and-back configuration.  This trail is such a beautiful section of singletrack winding through the deep aspens, definitely worth a hike!

places.name: Colorado Midland Ute Pass
places.directions: Drive on Hwy. 24 west out of Colorado Springs. Exit at the Cave Dwellings signal. Go down the off ramp onto Manitou Ave. Right across the intersection where the road meets Manitou Ave. There is a large dirt lot. Park here. Ride up Manitou Ave. (west) until you see the obvious trail head on the left side of the road.

activities.name: Colorado Midland Ute Pass
activities.description: Explore 6 130 year old train tunnels along the Colorado Midland Ute. This trail is full of history as the tunnels will show, but make sure you bring a flashlight along. It is recommended that you hike with a partner on this trail instead of alone.

places.name: CDT CO32: Berthoud Pass to Rainbow Road
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO32: Berthoud Pass to Rainbow Road
activities.description: Section 32 of the CDT runs for 9.5 miles from Berthoud Pass to Rainbow Road. Along the way, the trail passes Colorado Mines Peak, and the peak of Mount Flora.

places.name: Flume Canyon
places.directions: Flume Canyon shares a trailhead with Pollock Bench.  From Fruita drive south over the Interstate and turn right onto King's View Court across from the rodeo area just after crossing the river.  Follow the road around; it will turn to gravel.  Follow the road past the Devil's Canyon turn-off and all the way until you see a "dead end" sign.  On the left you'll see the parking area.

activities.name: Flume Canyon
activities.description: From the parking area walk straight past the bathroom to find the F1 trail.  After 6/10 of a mile you'll come to the start of the loop.  I like to go right and then loop around.  You can combine a part of the Flume trail with the Pollock trail by taking F2 when you come to that junction later on.  A great 5 mile hike, the upper portion is sandy and follows along some rock walls; the lower portion cuts through a damp wash before climbing back onto some rocky areas.  Gorgeous scenery!

places.name: Colorado Trail / Junction Creek
places.directions: Driving north through Durango, turn left (west) onto 25th Street.  This becomes Junction Street and then becomes Junction Creek Road.  The mileage and map for this route begins at the second (smaller) trailhead where the road switches back and starts to climb.  This allows you to avoid some of the families and dog-walkers that use the lower section of the trail.

activities.name: Colorado Trail / Junction Creek
activities.description: This route is the southwestern terminus of the famous Colorado Trail. It's a great out-and-back from the Junction Creek Trailhead, or keep going and you can backpack for days. This well-maintained, and at times popular, trail will keep you climbing for 9 miles up the mountain until you reach a high point. Enjoy the views from up there because you'll have earned them!

places.name: Palmer Trail / Section 16
places.directions: From I-25, take US 24 West to 21st St.  Turn left onto 21st street, then right onto Lower Gold Camp Road.  At the four way stop, turn left onto Bear Creek Road.  Park on the side of the road at the end of Bear Creek Road or the parking lot at the ranger station at the end of High Drive.

activities.name: Palmer Trail / Section 16
activities.description: Palmer Trail/Section 16 is a scenic but popular hike that traverses the foothills near Colorado Springs. The path winds through old growth forest, skirts along pristine creeks, and provides stunning views of the nearby mountains. Just because this trail is popular, don't let that deter you from this awesome hike! Mountain bikers are also allowed on this trail, so please share the path!

places.name: River Trail
places.directions: From town, head down to the gondola and the river, the trail is right beside the river. Head west on the trail.

activities.name: River Trail
activities.description: An easy, fairly flat hike that starts and ends right in town. The trail follows the river and is fairly wide most of the way around.

places.name: Son Of Middle Creek
places.directions: Take I-70 to Vail heading west, get off at the second Vail exit.  Take your second turn off the roundabout on the frontage road.  Take the frontage road to red sandstone road and follow the road to the first large pullout in front of you.

activities.name: Son Of Middle Creek
activities.description: Son Of Middle Creek is a 10 mile loop trail that offers beautiful views. Hike through scenic aspen forests and then enjoy the scenery as the tree cover opens up and showcases the beautiful surroundings.  This is a multi-use trail so be sure to share the path.

places.name: Colorado Hills Trail
places.directions: Church Ranch Road west to Simms, head north on Simms to 105th.   Trailhead is on left at 105th and Simms.

activities.name: Colorado Hills
activities.description: Walk this trail through the Westminister's Colorado Hills Open Space and you'll find yourself at a scenic 11-acre pond. Although this trail is near to the city, it feels like it's completely secluded.

places.name: CDT CO08: Twin Lakes to Beartown Trailhead
places.directions: Google Maps location given is for Twin Lakes, but it if you are just going to hike this section, it is easiest to park at Beartown Trailhead on the northern end: lat=37.712333, lon=-107.518005

activities.name: CDT CO08: Twin Lakes to Beartown Trailhead
activities.description: The Continental Divide Trail measures 10 miles in length between Twin Lakes and the Beartown Trailhead. Along the way the trail passes Hunchback Mountain, Hunchback Pass, White Dome, Vallecito Lake, Ute Creek, and Nebo Creek.

places.name: The Ribbon
places.directions: From Grand Junction, travel west on Grand Avenue, which turns into Broadway.  Cross over two bridges, at the next stop light, turn left on to Monument Road.  Turn left just before you cross the ditch on to D Rd.  Travel approximately 1 mile to where D Rd ends, go right on to Little Park Rd.  Travel approximately  2.5 miles to the Little Park Road Staging Area (First Flats) on the left, park here.

activities.name: The Ribbon
activities.description: The Ribbon Trailhead provides access to the top end of the Ribbon Trail which snakes its way down massive slickrock slabs, past towering Ponderosa pines, and along a narrow ribbon of slickrock sloping toward the canyons below. Sweeping vistas of the Grand Mesa, Grand Valley, and Little Bookcliffs are another highlight of this trail. This is an out-and-back trail, so in total you'll be hiking about 8 miles.

places.name: Little Rainbow
places.directions: Approaching Salida from the East on Highway 50, look for the left turn onto the not-so-well marked Burmac Road.  If you see an old garage with a Big O Tires sign out front, you just passed it.  Double back and take the first right then grab the first left that quickly dumps into a parking area.  Park here.

activities.name: Little Rainbow
activities.description: Hike along the base of Methodist Mountain on this well-maintained trail. The trail will take you through valleys of low-lying shrubs and then up the mountain for beautiful views of the surrounding area.  This trail is designed specifically for mountain bikers so be aware that there will be bike traffic here. Please share the path and practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Kipp's Loop
places.directions: Exit 163 (County Line Road) on I-25. Go west 2 miles to Greenland Open Space parking lot, on the right (about .25 miles NE of town of Palmer Lake)

activities.name: Kipp's Loop
activities.description: Kipp's Loop takes you on an 8 mile trail that wanders through wide open prairie grass fields, and along ponderosa forests. It's fairly flat and easy, but it offers beautiful views of the Front Country and the Rampart Range.  Keep an eye out for mountain bikers and joggers, and be sure to share the path.

places.name: Animas City Trail
places.directions: From 32nd turn West and go dowm two or three blocks until the road dead ends turn right and follow the road until pavement ends. From there it's pretty obvious where the trail is.

activities.name: Animas City
activities.description: Animas City Trail climbs 1,500 feet in just 3 miles, making it a difficult trail, but great for a serious workout. The trail is well-maintained and leads you up to beautiful views of downtown Durango. Check out views of the Animas Valley and Turtle Lake as well on this scenic loop trail.

places.name: Trail around Bierstadt Lake
places.directions: Enter Rocky Mountain National Park from the main entrance at Estes Park. Go past the Beaver Meadows Visitor Center and turn left onto Bear Lake Road. Follow this road until you come to Bierstadt Lake Trailhead on the left hand side.After hiking 1.6 miles up this trail you will be at Bierstadt Lake. This is where the trail around the lake starts.

activities.name: Trail around Bierstadt Lake
activities.description: Trail goes through a forest of aspen trees around Bierstadt Lake.

places.name: Round Mountain Summit Trail
places.directions: From I-25 take the Loveland/Estes Park exit.  Turn left on hwy 34 west (Eisenhower) and continue through the Big Thomson Canyon.  After passing The Dam Store, continue an additional 4 miles and the trail head parking lot will be on your left.  It is not well marked, all that is on the main road is a brown sign wih an arrow that says "parking".  If you hit the fork at drake, you went way too far.

activities.name: Round Mountain Summit Trail
activities.description: Moderate to difficult hike mainly due to the uphill nature and the length.  This trail has some of the best viewpoints in the area.  It's variety of terrain keeps interesting the entire way.  There are a few camp spots.  One located approx. 2 miles up the trail.  The other couple are located at the top, 4.75miles.  Watch out for the afternoon thunderstorms that go hand in hand with the local climate during the peak seasons.

places.name: CDT CO24: Halfmoon Creek to Timberline Lake
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO24: Halfmoon Creek to Timberline Lake
activities.description: Section 24 of the CDT runs 13 miles from Halfmoon Creek to Timberline Lake. Along the way, the trail passes North Willow Creek, Rock Creek, Hagerman Road, Busk Creek, Mount Massive (elevation 14,421), the Mount Massive Wilderness Area, County Road 4, and Turquoise Lake.

places.name: Black Canyon National Forest
places.directions: Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park is located approximately 250 miles southwest of Denver.South Rim: 15 miles east of Montrose, via U.S. Highway 50 and CO Highway 347North Rim: 11 miles south of Crawford, via CO Highway 92 and North Rim Road (unpaved)There is no bridge between the north and south rims of the canyon. Allow two to three hours to drive from one side to the other.Source: National Park Service

activities.name: Black Canyon National Forest
activities.description: 20 miles of trails  exist with in park. Many trails pass by steep dropoffs, so be cautious and keep a close watch on children.There are no maintained or marked trails into the inner canyon. Routes are difficult to follow, and only individuals in excellent physical condition should attempt these hikes. Source: National Park Service

places.name: CDT CO37: Bowen Gulch to Willow Creek Pass
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO37: Bowen Gulch to Willow Creek Pass
activities.description: The CDT runs for 19.7 miles from Bownen Gulch to Willow Creek Pass on Hwy 125. Along the way the trail passes the Colorado River, Bowen Creek, Ruby Mountain, Cascade Mountain, and Radial Mountain.

places.name: Spring Brook Loop
places.directions: From Highway 93, take Highway 170 west about 1.8 miles, then turn left into the Doudy Draw trailhead.

activities.name: Spring Brook Loop
activities.description: Spring Brook Loop is a 5 mile hiking trail in Eldorado Springs, Colorado.

places.name: Mount Herman Trail
places.directions: from northbound I-25 Take the monument exit, turn left at the first light right at the second, left at 7-11 travle all the way down that road until you come to the RR crossing. go across the tracks and turn left then turn right at mt. herman road.  [Added 6/9/02 by webmaster]: Take exit #161 off I-25.  Head west and take the second left, Third Street.  Follow this as it curves around and becomes Front Street.  Turn right at the stop sign onto Second St.  After crossing the railroad tracks, turn left onto Mitchell St.  Mt. Herman Rd. will be about a half mile on the right.  Go about a mile or so and turn into the signed parking lot on the left.  The trail starts here and heads west.

activities.name: Mount Herman Trail
activities.description: Mount Herman Trail offers a wide range of trails that take you through aspen forests, along creek beds, up to the summit, or out in wide open fields.

places.name: Monarch Crest Trail
places.directions: From Salida, head west on US 50 to Poncha Springs.  Head south on 285 for less than a quarter of a mile and park one vehicle at the gas station/shuttle parking area (they charge $5 per vehicle).  Now head up US 50 west to the top of Monarch Pass and park in the parking area on the left.  The trail starts up the dirt road.

activities.name: CDT CO18: Marshall Pass to Monarch Pass (Monarch Crest Trail)
activities.description: Monarch Crest is an epic alpine trail that spends a significant amount of time above tree line. It offers gorgeous views of the surrounding mountains which are lush with vegetation: a distinct change from the front range of Colorado. This trail is quite popular with backpackers and mountain bikers, but it is great for a short day hike as well. CDT Description: Section 18 of the CDT in Colorado runs 10.7 miles from Marshall Pass to Monarch Pass and US Hwy 50. Along the way the trail passes Mount Ouray, Pahlone Peak, Mount Peck, and Monarch Ridge. The trailhead listed is for the northern end of this section. The southern end is located at lat= 38.39166 lon= -106.24696

places.name: Red Mountain Open Space
places.directions: Take State Hwy 1/Terry Lake Rd to CR15 (aka the Waverly turn off) - go north (left) on CR15, turn west (left) on CR78, turn north (right) on CR17, turn west (left) on CR80, turn north (right) on CR19 (pass gravel pit on left), turn left on CR21. Go over several cattle guards, traveling about 7 miles on CR21 which will end at the trailhead parking area.

activities.name: Red Mountain Open Space
activities.description: Deep crimson and tan rocks, rolling grasslands, and sandy washes await you at Red Mountain Open Space, an almost 15,000-acre open space in northeastern Colorado. From the trailhead, hikers, bikers, and horseback riders can take off on over 15 miles of multi-use trails.  Then, they can access the trails in two adjacent protected areas that are part of a much larger vision - the Laramie Foothills Mountains to Plains Project - which protects over 55,000 acres of ecologically and culturally diverse landscape.

places.name: Warren Gulch
places.directions: Take I-70 west of Denver to  Idaho Springs

activities.name: Warren Gulch
activities.description: Warren Gulch is a high altitude trail located right outside of Idaho Springs. The trail is made of rocky singletrack that makes its way up the mountain with switchbacks. All the climbing will be worth it when you break out of the heavy forest and enjoy the stunning views! This is a multi-use trail, so please share the path.

places.name: Dyke
places.directions: From Crested Butte, go west for 12 miles on Kebler Pass Road (country road 12).  You can park at various places.  Typically you would choose either trailhead (the Lake Irwin or Horse Ranch Park) or the top of Kebler Pass.

activities.name: Dyke
activities.description: This is a gorgeous, high-altitude trail that offers up amazing views of the nearby mountain peaks. Also, this trail goes through the Kebler Pass aspen grove, one of the largest aspen groves & largest living organisms on the planet! Hiking this trail is worth it just for the aspens!

places.name: Ceran Saint Vrain Loop
places.directions: From Intersection of Broadway and Canyon in Boulder, go 3.4 miles north on Broadway to Lee Hill Road.  Take Lee Hill Road to Old Stage Road and go 4 miles to Lefthand Canyon Road, go left 2 miles to County Road 94 to Jamestown, go 4.7 miles to the enterance for Ceran Saint Vrain, turn right into the trailhead parking lot.  (Information provided by "Mountain Biking Denver and Boulder")  a Simpler way would be to go north(or west as the book says) on Highway 36, there will be a sign for Jamestown where you will take a left, continue untill you reach the Ceran Saint Vrain parking lot enterance on the right, don't drive to fast or you'll fly right past it as I have a few times:o)

activities.name: Ceran Saint Vrain Loop
activities.description: The Ceran Saint Vrain Trail is an easy trail that gradually loses elevation as it follows the South Saint Vrain Creek downstream for 1.9 miles. The trail ends at National Forest System Road 252, a rough four-wheel drive road. This road climbs 0.5 miles northwest to a four-way intersection from which it is a steep half-mile to the left up to Miller Rock. Miller Rock is a scenic high-point that offers 360-degree views.

places.name: Overend Mountain Park
places.directions: There are a variety of trailheads accessing this network of trails.  To get you acquainted with the northern sector, suggest turning west on 22nd Street off Camino del Rio (Hwy 550) and driving to the end of Montview or jogging a block to the right and park at the end of Crestview.

activities.name: Overend Mountain Park
activities.description: Overend Mountain Park is a 5 mile hiking trail in Durango, Colorado.

places.name: Reservoir Ridge
places.directions: From Fort Collins, head north on Overland Trail.  From Laporte, head south on Overland Trail.  Overland Trail makes a series of turns, Michaud Lane is in the elbow of the 90 degree turn.  Head down Michaud Lane to the end, this puts you right into the parking lot for Reservoir Ridge Natural Area next to Claymore Lake.

activities.name: Reservoir Ridge
activities.description: Reservoir Ridge is a 3 mile hiking trail in Fort Collins, Colorado.

activities.name: Reservoir Ridge
activities.description: 3 mile hiking trail located near Fort Collins, Colorado

places.name: Buffehr Creek Th North Vail Trail To Davos Towers
places.directions: Heading West on US I-70 in Vail Colorado head east on the northern frontage road to Buffehr Creek Road.  Turn left heading north for two tenths of a mile to the North Vail Trail Buffehr Creek parking area.  Parking is from 7 AM to 11 PM, and only three hours (as of 060110, new rules) with no overnight parking.  Hiking trip on this route takes 3 hours, biking takes about 1.5 depending on your skills.

activities.name: Buffehr Creek The North Vail Trail To Davos Towers
activities.description: This trail starts out flat, but once you hit the switchbacks you've got about 1,800 feet of climbing to do. Follow the trail through the forest, and come out on top to enjoy the views of Edwards, Avon, Minturn, Meadow Mountain and Vail. All of that hard climbing is totally worth it!

places.name: Durango Mountain Resort (purgatory)
places.directions: From Durango, take US 550 north about 30 miles to Durango Mountain Resort, located on the left side of the highway.

activities.name: Durango Mountain Resort (purgatory)
activities.description: Durango Mountain Resort (purgatory) is a 40 mile hiking trail in Hermosa, Colorado.

places.name: Ute Creek Trail (Loop)
places.directions: From Creede take Hwy 149 towards Lake City and turn left onto FS road 520.  Follow the signs about 10 miles to Thirty Mile Campground and continue to the other side of the reservoir.  You'll see a bathroom, parking area and sign on the left. Park here and begin.

activities.name: Ute Creek Trail (Loop)
activities.description: After a quick ford of the river you can hike as far as you want.  The loop we do involves the Ute Creek, CDT and West Ute Lake trails.

places.name: Buffalo Pass To Mountain View Trail
places.directions: From Steamboat, take 6th St. north, make a right on Missouri Ave. then a left on N. Park Ave.  Take this north until it turns into Routt Co. 38.  About 2 miles north you will hit a FR 60 on the right and a sign which points to Buffalo Pass.  It is about 13 miles up to the pass.

activities.name: Buffalo Pass To Mountain View Trail
activities.description: Buffalo Pass To Mountain View Trail passes through beautiful meadows along ridgelines that provide incredibly scenic views of the surrounding area. This well-marked trail winds through forests and skirts around lakes, and makes for a seriously beautiful hike. This section of the trail is multi-use so please practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Emerald Mountain
places.directions: Take 5th street heading south/west from downtown and cross the river. Several parking areas near the ski area.

activities.name: Emerald Mountain
activities.description: Emerald Mountain is a 40 mile hiking trail in Steamboat Springs, Colorado.

places.name: Colorado Trail / Kenosha Pass To Lost Creek Wilderness Bound
places.directions: Going South on 285 from Bailey, hang a left at the Colorado trail parking lot on Kenosha pass (not right, but left as you\'re going south.)

activities.name: Colorado Trail / Kenosha Pass To Lost Creek Wilderness Bound
activities.description: This section of trail is 6.5 miles one-way and is 13 miles round trip if you hike it as an out-and-back. At first it passes through a few beautiful aspen groves, and then the singletrack pops out into an open alpine field with some spectacular views of the South Park Valley. This is definitely a must-hike trail!

places.name: Williams Canyon
places.directions: Head west on Manitou Avenue until you can make a right on Canyon Avenue.  Follow Canyon Avenue (it will bear right after a couple block) until you come to the underpass under Highway 24 and look for a place to park.  IMPORTANT NOTE:  this trail crosses private property owned by the Cave of the Winds and you can only legally access it if you turn in a waiver at the ticket desk there.  Be sure to do that before you head for the trail.  Waiver available at http://www.inclineclub.com/caveofthewinds.pdf

activities.name: Williams Canyon
activities.description: Williams Canyon is a 5 mile out-and-back trail that winds through the canyon and brings you to a beautiful waterfall. The hike passes by deep caves, fields of wildflowers, an old stone house, and some zip lines as well. Enjoy the beautiful canyon scenery as you explore this trail!

places.name: Ken Caryl Valley
places.directions: West of Denver in the foothills near the Ken Caryl Valley Housing area.  Drive west of Denver on C470.  Exit on Ken Caryl Drive and drive into the valley.  Park just west of the first stoplight and start on the trail head for Kathy Johnson trail.

activities.name: Ken Caryl Valley
activities.description: Head out to the Ken Caryl Ranch and enjoy over 20 miles of trail in the 4,800-acres of foothills open space. There are 10 trails here ranging from easy to difficult, with the longest trail topping out at 3.8 miles. All of these trails but one are private trails, only open to residents. The Cathy Johnson Trail and South Hogback Open Space is the only trail that's open to the public. It's a 2.1 mile trail that ranges from easy to moderate along the trail.

places.name: Sandbeach Lake
places.directions: Located between the towns of Meeker and Allenspark on Colorado route 7 (Peak to Peak Scenic Highway). Watch for signs.

activities.name: Sandbeach Lake
activities.description: This is a tough 2,000 foot elevation gain on a rocky mountain path. Be prepared to spend a day hiking out and back. Along the way you'll hike through dense forests, skirt a beautiful alpine lake, and enjoy the views of the surrounding area.

places.name: CDT CO40: FR104 to Rabbit Ears Pass
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO40: FR104 to Rabbit Ears Pass
activities.description: The CDT runs just under 30 miles from Forest Road 104 to US Hwy 40. Along the way, the trail passes Little Haystack Mountain, Dennis Hump, North Ryder Peak, Ironclad Mountain, Hwy 14, Mexican Ridge South, Diamond Mountain, US Hwy 40, and Baker Mountain.

places.name: Wetterhorn Basin / West Fork of the Cimmaron
places.directions: To get here from Grand Junction, Colorado, drive south towards Ridgway and turn left onto the Owl Creek Pass road. Just past Owl Creek Pass, turn right onto the West Fork road. Drive as far as you can. If you have a truck, or even a higher clearance Subaru, you will be able to make it almost all the way down the gravel road. Hike across the creek and into the West Fork Basin. Where the trail becomes indistinct look for cairns and head up towards an obvious pass area. Be prepared for a very loose, exposed section of scree and talus. It's fairly intimidating and scary for about 3 minutes. Head up and over West Fork Pass; follow the signs on the way down for Wetterhorn Basin. Just after crossing the creek and heading up the opposite bank, where the trail seems to disappear, is your campsite. The trail actually continues to the left, through the meadow towards Wetterhorn Pass. Look for posts and cairns along the way.

activities.name: Wetterhorn Basin / West Fork of the Cimmaron
activities.description: Beautiful and mostly remote hike with only one technical section. Best to have trekking poles and a camera!

places.name: West Monument Creek Trail #713
places.directions: Enter the Air Force Academy at the south gate. Turn left on Pine Drive, then left on W. Monument Creek Drive. Trailhead parking at the end of the road on the right.

activities.name: West Monument Creek Trail #713
activities.description: Loop hike that takes you past the Tesla Plant and up a steep canyon until finally dropped back via Stanley Canyon trail. The 713 trail is rarely crowded - in fact each time I've hiked past the Tesla plant I've seen no one.

places.name: Goat Camp Creek
places.directions: Head for the visitors center on the Academy.  Across from the entrance is a dirt road, stay right, that will lead you to a parking lot.  The trail head is just up the jeep trail.  N39 00.422 x W104 54.257

activities.name: Goat Camp Creek
activities.description: Goat Camp Creek to Eagle Peak is a tough ascent.  The short distance is all up with only a short reprieve in the saddle.  Consistent traffic on the trail keeps the path cut all year long but the ice will try to deter you.

places.name: Moore Fun
places.directions: From I -70 take Loma exit 15 go south to frontage rd. to Kokopelli Trail parking area.

activities.name: Moore Fun
activities.description: This out-and-back trail is part of the Kokopelli Trail system, which means you can link it up with other trails to make it longer, or to use it as a loop. Most of the hike is spent climbing a rocky line with plenty of ledges. Look around because the views along this trail are stunning.  This trail is very popular with mountain bikers, as is this whole area, so please practice trail etiquette and share the trail.

places.name: White Ranch
places.directions: From Denver, take 70W to Golden.  White Ranch State Park is ~2miles north of Golden and ~17 miles south of Boulder on Hwy 93.   Turn west (right if coming from Golden) onto W 56th Ave and follow the signs to the parking lot.

activities.name: White Ranch
activities.description: White Ranch has a wide variety of trails, from really rocky cactus-lined tracks to wooden bridges. There are several great views of Golden, Denver, and the Front Range.

places.name: Mosquito Lake (Bear River Trail) (#1120)
places.directions: From Yampa take County Road 7 (turns into Forest Road 900) to the end.  Park at Stillwater Resevoir.  The trail follows along side the reservoir.

activities.name: Mosquito Lake (Bear River Trail) (#1120)
activities.description: Trail starts at 10,200 feet and climbs to approximately 11,400 over 2.5 miles.  The lake is in a bowl with fantastic views on all sides.  On the days without a breeze it is aptly named.

places.name: CDT CO16: CO Hwy 114 to Sargents Mesa
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO16: CO Hwy 114 to Sargents Mesa
activities.description: Section 16 of the CDT runs for just over 20 miles from CO Hwy 114 to Sargents Mesa. Along the way the trail passes through some high forests as well as Long Branch Baldy.

places.name: Golden Gate Canyon State Park
places.directions: Golden Gate Canyon SP is a short 30 miles from Denver. Follow I-70 west to exit 265 for highway 58. Take highway 58 west to highway 93. Turn right (north) on highway 93 for approximately 1 mile to Golden Gate Canyon road. Turn left and follow Golden Gate Canyon road 13 miles to the Visitor Center. The campground is approximately 5 miles from the Visitor Center( in the summer when Mountain Base Rd is open. In winter continue on Hwy 46 West 3 mi to Hwy 119 go north on Hwy 119 4mi to mile marker 15.5 approximately and look for Gap Rd on your right). RVs or vehicles towing large trailers must continue west to Hwy 119 all seasons.
places.description: The Golden Gate Canyon State Park offers 12,000 acres of dense wooded areas, rocky mountain peaks, and aspen laden meadows. Miles of trails are available for the avid hiker, biker, camper or horseback rider. Winter sports are also exciting and popular here during the cold months. The park offers several amenities such as the 132 campsites, various backcountry camping shelters, electrical hook-ups, toilets, and laundry facilities, among many more.

activities.name: Golden Gate Canyon State Park
activities.description: More than 12,000 acres of dense forest, rocky peaks, and aspen-rimmed meadows laced with miles of trails awaiting the hiker, horseback rider, mountain biker and winter sports enthusiast at Golden Gate Canyon State Park. Only 30 miles from Denver, Golden Gate Canyon offers such amenities as a electrical hook-ups and tent-sites in two different campgrounds, stocked fishing ponds, picnic sites and the Panorama Point Scenic Overlook, where visitors can see 100 miles of the Continental Divide.  Over 35 miles of hiking trails in the park offer pleasures and challenges for everyone. The twelve trails at Golden Gate Canyon are each named after an animal and marked with the animal's footprint. Trail head parking areas are easily accessible from the main roads in the park. Mountain bikes and horses are permitted in the park on multiple-use  trails.

places.name: Chimney Gulch
places.directions: This trail starts just below Lookout Mtn in Golden.  The easiest way to get there is to take Hwy 6 North from I-70 for about 2 miles.  Just before you reach the Hwy 58 intersection you will notice a small dirt pullout on the left side.  Jeffco Open space has a great map of this park/trail.  The park is called Windy Saddle.

activities.name: Chimney Gulch
activities.description: Chimney Gulch Trail is in the Jefferson County trail system and is connected to the Windy Saddle Trail and Park. The trail climbs to 2,000 feet in 2.5 miles from Highway 6 to the summit at Lookout Mountain Nature Center. The trail is moderate to advanced and passes through grass prairie and pine forest, crossing streams at several places.

places.name: CDT CO36: Grand Lake to Bowen Gulch
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO36: Grand Lake to Bowen Gulch
activities.description: Section 36 of the CDT in Colorado runs a length 28.2 miles from Grand Lake to Bowen Gulch. Note: there is also a possible shortcut to shorten this section. Along the way, the trail passes Green Mountain, Mount Patterson, Taylor Peak, The Sharkstooth, Otis Peak, Hallett Peak, Joe Mills Mountain, Sprague Mountain, Nakai Peak, and US Hwy 34.

places.name: Manitou Springs Incline
places.directions: Manitou Springs exit from 24 west. Left on Ruxton, continue on Hydro street towards the Cog Railway. Hard to find parking on weekends.

activities.name: The Incline
activities.description: This "incline" is like climbing a ladder.  8,585 ft and 2,610 steps ( at least according to the last step of the incline) Looking up all you see are vast wooden planks that continue endlessly.

places.name: Meyer Ranch Park
places.directions: Take HWY 285 west out of Denver to about 1/2 mile east of Aspen Park. Trailhead and parking are on the southside of the road.

activities.name: Meyer Ranch Park
activities.description: Rolling hay meadows lead to forested hillsides, with the ever-present chatter of pine squirrels and the rustle of quaking aspen leaves. The landscape invites one to meander and explore this exquisite park.Previously a working ranch, Meyer Ranch Park offers peaceful strolls through wildflower-laden meadows, lodgepole pine forests and aspen groves. There are a total of 4 hiking trails here: Owl's Perch Trail (.5mi), Lodgepole Loop Trail (1.2mi), Sunny Aspen Trail (.8mi), and Ole Ski Run Trail (1.3mi).

places.name: Keystone Gulch
places.directions: From I-70, take Highway 6 to Keystone.  At the first stoplight make a right then immediate left at the T.  Turn right on Soda Ridge Road then left on Keystone Gulch Road (dirt).  Parking area is on left and obvious.

activities.name: Keystone Gulch
activities.description: This trail takes you through beautiful and dense forests that pass beaver ponds and creeks along the way. You'll start to take switchbacks up the mountain until you reach the timber line where you'll get to enjoy incredible views of the surrounding area!

places.name: Spruce Meadow
places.directions: The Spruce Meadow trail head is off of I-25 at exit 167.  This is between Monument and Castle Rock.  After exiting I-25, turn West.  Follow the road for about 1 mile. The road will cross 2 railroad tracks.  The trail head is located left (South) after the 2nd railroad crossing.  The parking lot is very large and is very easy to see from the road.

activities.name: Spruce Mountain
activities.description: The Spruce Mountain Trail gently switchbacks up Spruce Mountain through a ponderosa pine and Douglas fir forest up to fabulous rocky overlooks and a loop around the fairly-flat, forested mountaintop. The first lookout offers breathtaking views of Greenland Open Space, surrounding buttes, Pikes Peak, the Palmer Divide, Carpenter Creek and thousands of acres of protected open space.  There are plenty of opportunities to gaze off rocky lookouts, ridges and meadows from over 8 miles of trails. Bring your camera.  For variety, descend on the service road, hike the loop to the west, and hike back along the Eagle Pass trail.

places.name: Colorado Trail / Green Mountain
places.directions: From Colorado Springs, take US 24 to Woodland Park.  Turn right onto CO 67 and go to Deckers.  Continue straight onto CO 126 approximately 15 miles.  Turn left onto road 550.  Parking lot is on the right.  There is a $4 daily use fee.

activities.name: Colorado Trail / Green Mountain
activities.description: Colorado Trail / Green Mountain features 16 miles of hiking trails near Deckers, CO.

places.name: Bear Creek Regional Park
places.directions: From I-25, exit at US 24 West, Cimmaron St. Head west. At the second stoplight (21st St.), turn left.The trail is on the right after the big hill. Parking is available on the right.

activities.name: Bear Creek Regional Park
activities.description: Bear Creek Regional Park is an extremely popular park, mainly for its stellar dog parks, with 3 miles covering a total of 575 acres. There are some walking paths that wind throughout the park for visitors to enjoy.

places.name: Galloping Goose
places.directions: Trail starts across from the Conoco at the 145 junction.

activities.name: Galloping Goose
activities.description: This rail-trail follows an old railroad grade into Ilium valley and goes about 15 miles one way. The trail leads over 20 scenic foot bridges, past many historical landmarks, and through the Uncompahgre National Forest.  Good out and back that's fairly flat - just turn around before you start feeling tired!

places.name: Red Hill
places.directions: From Glenwood Springs take hwy 82 south to Carbondale. At the intersection of hwy 133 and Hwy 82 turn left onto county road 107. Park there, its that simple. Begin your ride up CR 107 for about 1 mile you will find the entrance to Red Rill Park on your left.

activities.name: Red Hill
activities.description: Red Hill Recreation Area is a network of trails that all lead to the summit of Mushroom Rock. The paths are usually rocky and lined with low-lying desert shrubs, and the views from the top are absolutely stunning! Please share the path with mountain bikers!

places.name: Winter Park Resort
places.directions: To get to Winter Park Resort from all points around the Denver area, find your way to I-70 heading West out of Denver. Follow I-70 West approximately 40 miles to Exit 232 to Winter Park, Empire and Granby. Follow Exit 232 onto Hwy 40 which will take you over Berthoud Pass (great photo ops) and to Winter Park. Mileage from Exit 232 to Winter Park is approximately 24 miles. Total mileage from Denver is 67 miles.

activities.name: Winter Park Resort
activities.description: Winter Park Resort opens up their trails in the off-season. There's over 25 miles of trail that traverse the mountain and offer hikers and mountain bikers an amazing area to explore.

places.name: Aqueduct Trail
places.directions: From I-70 at Silverthorn take HWY 6 east to Keystone. At the stoplight, turn right onto Keystone Road. Turn left immediately, cross the Snake River. Turn right onto Soda Ridge Road. Park at Keystone Gulch on your left.

activities.name: Aqueduct
activities.description: Mainly this trail is used as a connector between the Keystone Gulch Trail and other trails like the Blair Witch and Colorado Trail. It's about 5 miles in total, follows a stream, crosses footbridges, and offers amazing views of the aqueduct. At times it has very steep up and downhills, so be ready for a workout. This is a multi-use trail so please use caution.

places.name: Curecanti National Recreation Area
places.directions: Curecanti National Recreation Area is located approximately 200 miles southwest of Denver.U.S. Highway 50 runs the length of Curecanti between Montrose and Gunnison, Colorado. The recreation area is also accessed from CO Hwy 149 and CO Hwy 92.Source: National Park Service

activities.name: Curecanti National Recreation Area
activities.description: Curecanti National Recreation Area is a series of three reservoirs along the once wild Gunnison River. The reservoirs that make up Curecanti today are a destination for water-based recreation high in the Rocky Mountains. Best known for salmon and trout fishing, Curecanti also offers opportunities for hiking, boating, camping, and bird watching. There are a total of 7 beautiful hiking trails within the recreation area, all ranging from 1.5 miles to 6 miles. It's the perfect place to get away with your family, or build your endurance on a tough hike.

places.name: Boulder Valley Ranch
places.directions: From Boulder, go north on US 36. Continue past Jay Rd. for 1.5 miles, and take a right on a dirt road. The Foothills trailhead is just a little farther on the left. There are several other trailheads too.

activities.name: Boulder Valley Ranch
activities.description: The Eagle (2.6 mile from Mesa Reservoir to Eagle Trailhead) and Sage Trails (1.8 mile [2.7 for whole Sage/Eagle Loop]) form a loop between this trailhead and the Eagle Trailhead. Heading southward on the Sage Trail you can either take this loop or head westward on the Cobalt Trail below an old smelter of 1930s to 1940s vintage and connect to the Eagle Trail as it heads toward the Foothills Trailhead.  Another option is to pass the Cobalt Trail (0.9 mile) and take the Eagle Trail as it turns up toward the now dry Mesa Reservoir. A loop hike is available in the Mesa Reservoir area by following the Hidden Valley (1.0 mile) and Mesa Reservoir Trails (0.8 mile).

places.name: Redskin Mountain
places.directions: From Colorado Springs, take US 24 to Woodland Park. Turn right onto CO 67 and go to Deckers. Continue straight onto CO 126 approximately 15 miles. Turn left onto FS Road 550.  Go about 10 miles, turn left onto FS Road 543 (Wellington Lake Rd.).  Parking is on the right at Colorado Trail sign.  From Denver, take Hwy 285 to Bailey and turn left onto County Rd 68.  Go approximately 9 miles, trailhead is on the right as described above.

activities.name: Redskin Mountain
activities.description: This portion of trail is a part of the Colorado Trail and it lies right next to the Buffalo Creek trail system, running right past the Buffalo Creek campground. As such, it is a beautiful piece of singletrack that is well-worth a hike!

places.name: Cherry Creek Trail
places.directions: Park anywhere legal near Colorado Blvd and the Alameda-Cherry Creek Drive area and head east on the Cherry Creek bike path.  Right before you get to the Four Mile House, you'll see a drop-in for the trail to your right.

activities.name: Cherry Creek Trail
activities.description: The Cherry Creek Trail is a fairly easy hike, being mostly flat with only a few technical sections.  However, one can get in a roughly 14-mile round trip if you do the entire thing (it ends a little ways past Evans/Iliff.)  It runs north/south between the bike path and the creek.  Sure, there are better hikes out there, but it's central location makes it a good after work hike and it's ease makes it good to take kids on.  There's lots of shade and even a couple of bars that serve food and cold drinks about a block from the trail on Iliff.  You'll likely encounter other hikers, trail runners, mountain bikers, and kids playing in the creek, so be alert, because there are a few blind corners.

places.name: Rustlers Loop
places.directions: Take I-70 to exit #15. The Kokopelli trailhead parking lot is just off the exit on Frontage road. Either park in the main lot or opt to drive over the hill and park in the small lot near the trailhead gate.

activities.name: Rustlers Loop
activities.description: This easy 3.5 mile loop takes you around the top of the mesa for stunning views of the Colorado River below. Canyon walls and desert bluffs surround you on this beautiful hike. Remember to share the path!

places.name: Gem Lake
places.directions: Directions from Estes Park: Drive north on MacGregor Avenue. Cross the Hwy 34 bypass and continue to a sharp right turn and sign for MacGregor Ranch. Follow the blacktop ranch road to the parking area.

activities.name: Gem Lake
activities.description: Gem Lake Trail is a 1.8 mile out and back trail located near Estes Park, Colorado that features a lake and is rated as moderate. The trail is primarily used for hiking and is accessible year-round.

places.name: Blodgett
places.directions: From I-25 take Woodmen Rd exit (149) and head west. Cross bridge over train-tracks. At next light Woodmen turns to the right, follow it. Stay on Woodmen for several miles (5 or so) as it passes a school on the left. At stop sign continue straight as it winds through sub-divisions. Woodmen gains in altitute as it head west and then it starts to run parallel to the range. On your right you will see a fire-road with a gate, a small sign identifies it as Blodget Open Space. Pull in and park or park on the street.

activities.name: Blodgett Peak
activities.description: Blodgett Peak hiking trail leads steeply up the mountain to a relatively-low elevation peak. However, the views from the top make the climb worth it, as it gives panoramic views of nearby Pikes Peak and the United States Air Force Academy.

places.name: Beaver Creek Ski Resort
places.directions: From Denver, take I-70 West to exit 167, Avon.  Follow the signs to the Beaver Creek Ski resort.  There is no parking once you're up the mountain so be sure to make arrangements.

activities.name: Beaver Creek Ski Resort
activities.description: Beaver Creek Ski Resort features 37 miles of multi-use trails with 7 trails reserved for hikers only. The hiking trails range from 1-6 miles in length and are rated as green, blue, and black according to their difficulty levels.  Some of these trails are perfect for families and pass by playgrounds, others summit mountains for scenic views of the surrounding area.

places.name: Bluffs Regional Park Trail
places.directions: From I-25 take Lincoln Ave east about one block to Ridgegate Parkway, take that south about 1/2 mile to the trailhead

activities.name: Bluffs Regional Park Trail
activities.description: Bluffs Regional Park Trail features 4 miles of hiking trails near Lone Tree, CO. There is a 2.7-mile loop of soft-surface trail (3.5 miles including the feeder trails and overlooks) that winds along the open country. Enjoy beautiful views of the surrounding area. This trail is perfect for families with children, but it is a multi-use trail so please practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Kodel Canyon
places.directions: Kodel Canyon shares a trailhead with Devil's Canyon.  From Fruita drive south across the Interstate and turn right onto King's View Court.  Follow the road as it turns to gravel and after a mile or so you'll see a parking area far out on the left and a sign for "Devil's Canyon."

activities.name: Kodel Canyon
activities.description: From the parking area follow the gravel road up and over a slight knoll.  Continue down the gravel road until you see a trail sign on the left for one of the "K" trails.  It's best to have a map (usually available at the parking area) to find your way through the myriad of trails in the Kodel Canyon section.

places.name: Rim Trail
places.directions: From Interstate 70, take the Glenwood Springs Exit and head South on highway 82. Approx. 35 miles, follow signs for Snowmass and turn right on Brush Creek Road.  After 5-7 miles, you will go under a skier bridge and soon after turn right onto Divide Road.  The trailhead is on the right on you will clearly see the parking across the road.

activities.name: Rim Trail
activities.description: Rim Trail takes you along the ridge of the mountain showcasing the stunning views that Snowmass has to offer. Even though you get amazing views on the trail, it's not too difficult besides the initial climbs. Please share the path with mountain bikers.

places.name: CDT CO35: Monarch Lake to Grand Lake
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO35: Monarch Lake to Grand Lake
activities.description: Section 35 of the CDT in Colorado runs 14.2 miles from Monarch Lake to Grand Lake. Along the way, the trail enters Rocky Mountain National Park and passes Lake Granby, Green Ridge, and Shadow Mountain Lake.

places.name: Arkansas Headwaters Recreation Area
places.directions: To get to the AHRA Visitor Center from the intersection of Highways 285/24 at Johnson Village, go south on Highway 285, drive 14 miles to Hwy 291, turn left, drive 8 miles to G St and turn left at the Skateboard Park. Go to the end of this block which intersects with Sackett Ave, parallel to the Arkansas River. The AHRA Visitor Center is the brick building with a blue roof on the corner of G and Sackett Streets. From the intersection of Highways 50/291, turn north on Hwy 291 (1st Street), go one block past the stop light to G Street, turn right 1 block to Sackett Ave, turn left. The Visitor center is on left corner of Sackett and G Streets.
places.description: The Arkansas Headwaters Recreation Area (AHRA) is recognized as one of the nation's most popular locations for whitewater rafting and kayaking on the Arkansas River - the most commercially rafted river in the United States!

activities.name: Arkansas Headwaters Recreation Area
activities.description: The AHRA has a wide variety of trails for every outdoor enthusiast, from the hiker to the to mountain biker and OHV rider. Hayden Meadows, at the northern end of AHRA, has ADA accessible interpretive and fishing trails, 5 wetland boardwalks, and 2 bridges surrounding a small reservoir. Collegiate Peaks Group Picnic Area: is at the head of both the Midland Bike Trail, Barbara Whipple Trail and Four Mile systems, which offer miles of scenic motorized and non-motorized routes for all skill levels. At the Ruby Mountain campground, both the FourMile trail system and the Browns Canyon Wilderness Study Area (WSA) can be accessed. FourMile is designated for both motorized and nonmotorized use, while Browns Canyon WSA is for nonmotorized use only. Below the Hecla Junction Campground a ¾ mile foot trail leads downstream along the shoreline to Seidel's Suckhole, which is a great place to watch and photograph whitewater rafting in the summer and offers excellent fishing in the spring and summer. Lone Pine Recreation Site has a designated river trail approximately 1/2 mile in length that begins near the restrooms and picnic site on the east end. This trail is used for wildlife and river viewing as well as fishing access. McIntyre Hills Wilderness Study Area (WSA) can be accessed from the Five Points Campground. A trail begins between campsites #4 and #5, but much of the McIntyre Hills WSA is comprised of undesignated, or social, trails. A trail map on the entrance station shows the trail's alignment.

places.name: Lair O' The Bear/Bear Creek Trail
places.directions: Take I-70 west from Denver to C-470. C-470 east to Morrison Rd. Morrison Rd west for about 7 miles to Lair O' the Bear open space park on the south side of the road.

activities.name: Lair O' The Bear/Bear Creek Trail
activities.description: Lair O' The Bear/Bear Creek Trail follows rolling terrain over open meadows and through thick forests. Hike alongside creeks and enjoy views of the mountains and the surrounding area. Parts of this trail are popular with families, and this entire out-and-back is popular with mountain bikers so be sure share the trail.

places.name: Buffalo Creek
places.directions: From Colorado Springs, take US 24 to Woodland Park. Turn right onto CO 67 and go to Deckers. Continue straight onto CO 126 approximately 20 miles.  Parking is on the right just before the bridge at the Buffalo Creek Forest Service Work Center.  The trail starts on Buffalo Creek road on the left of CO 126 just over the bridge.  Ride about 3 miles and turn right onto Baldy Trail and stay on Baldy through the climb.  Turn right onto Gashouse, and make your next turn right onto Miller Gulch Trail.  Go left onto the Homestead trail, then right on Charlie's Cutoff.  This becomes Sandy Wash trail, take this back down to Buffalo Creek Road.

activities.name: Buffalo Creek
activities.description: The Buffalo Creek trail system is at least 14 miles long and includes a number of different trails. The singletrack itself is fairly sandy and gravely. These trails offer some gorgeous views due to an old burn and they pass by some amazing rock formations. There's a nearby campground of the same name.  Note: this is a fairly popular mountain bike destination.

places.name: Colorado Trail
places.directions: Multiple trailheads around the state, click one of the individual segment listings above to get directions to a particular staring point. From Denver, start off S. Platte Canyon Rd.

activities.name: Colorado Trail
activities.description: The Colorado Trail offers amazing singletrack, incredible views, some steep high-altitude climbs, and it passes through 6 wilderness areas. It is probably Colorado's best long-distance backpacking trail.

places.name: Loch Vale Lake
places.directions: Navigate the Rocky Mountain National Park to the Bear Lake Parking Lot.  This is a map in the parking lot showing the route to Loch Lake.

activities.name: Loch Vale Lake
activities.description: Perfect Hike for a sunny afternoon to get up and out of the city.  Located in the beautiful Rocky Mountain National Park, the setting is one that will sweep you off your feet.  Great place for lunch or dinner.

places.name: Standley Lake
places.directions: Take US-36 to Sheridan Blvd exit.  Turn Left at Sheridan Blvd.  Turn right on 88th Ave.  Continue on 88th Avenue to W 86th Pkwy.  At Simms Street, make a right onto trail head parking.

activities.name: Standley Lake
activities.description: Standley Lake Regional Park boasts more than 14 miles of maintained trails, single-track trails and roads that are available to hiking, mountain biking and horse back riding. Maintained trails, which make up the majority of the park's system, offer a variety of terrain that appeals to most hikers and horseback riders.There are just a few steep hills, but they will reward you with breathtaking overlooks of Standley Lake and the Front Range. While using the trails within the park, you have the opportunity to see many of the plants and animals common to this area, including native grasses, wildflowers, cottonwoods, prairie dogs, cotton-tailed rabbits, hawks and meadowlarks, just to name a few. Standley Lake Regional Park is also the starting point for some of the city's major trail corridors, including the the Big Dry Creek Trail and the Farmers' High Line Canal Trail. In addition, there is a substantial network of trails on the south side of the lake. Many of the trails link to others throughout the city's network of more than 63 miles of off-road trails.

places.name: Limekiln
places.directions: from Monte Vista, go west on Hwy 160 for about 6.3 miles to County Road 5W. Turn south (left) onto BLM road 5120 and go 4.1 miles and park.

activities.name: Limekiln
activities.description: Enjoy the San Luis Valley on this 6 mile out-and-back trail that takes you through a desert terrain and overlooks Colorado's beautiful front range. Make sure to bring extra water out here, and remember to share the trail with mountain bikers!

places.name: Black Forest Regional Park
places.directions: From Colorado Springs, take Black Forest Road north into the Black Forest.  Turn left onto Shoup Rd. at the second light you see.  The park is on the right about 2 miles down Shoup.

activities.name: Black Forest Regional Park
activities.description: This park includes 427 acres and is located approximately four miles east of Interstate 25 on Shoup Road.  As suggested by its name, the character of Black Forest Park is dominated by the presence of the ponderosa pine forest. The developed area, with turf playfields, tennis courts and two picnic pavilions, were developed in natural openings of the forest.  A six mile, loop trail used for non-motorized recreation winds through the park.

places.name: Walker Ranch
places.directions: In Boulder, use Flagstaff Rd. @ Chatauqua park go about 6 or 7 miles.  Has A small dirt road on left (south) side to reach trailhead.    Watch for cyclists climbing Flagstaff Rd. From Golden, go north on Hwy 93 to Coal Creek Canyon dr. (Hwy 72) take a left and go approx 8mi to Gross Dam rd on the right, road may not be marked but it is ~.5mi past the Boulder County sign.  Take a very sharp right onto this dirt rd (nearly 180deg) and go 2.7mi to the Crescent Meadow parking lot on the right, just past the railroad tracks.

activities.name: Walker Ranch
activities.description: Sporting a diverse array of ecosystems to explore, it's virtually impossible to get bored at Walker Ranch. From the great staircase to South Boulder Creek to the open view across Crescent Meadow to the historic homestead, Walker Ranch is a cultural and natural treasure.   There are 3 trails here: Meyers Homestead Trail, Walker Ranch Loop, and Walker Ranch Link.

places.name: Dwight's
places.directions: From Denver: West on I-70, Exit at Frisco and to south on highway 9, there should be signs for Brekenridge, stay on 9 to Breckenridge. then turn right(west) in Lincoln Ave, this will take you to a parking lot where the ski lift are. From parking lot, go up the stairs, then go directly left, you'll see the trail going up the hill(where Pioneer Trail starts) Dwight's is on the right, but I don't think u want to climb it!  Or just buy a lift ticket up to the trailhead on top of the mountain.  There are Trail maps available at the ticket window

activities.name: Dwight's
activities.description: Dwight's Trail is a 3 mile trail (6-out-and-back) within the Breckenridge skiing area. Either hike up for a great out-and-back trail or take the lift up and hike the 3 miles down. Enjoy beautiful aspen forests and stunning mountaintop views! This trail is multi-use is watch out for mountain bikers.

places.name: Rough Canyon
places.directions: Take Little Park Road to the main Bangs Canyon parking lot.  Follow the signs to Rough Canyon.

activities.name: Rough Canyon
activities.description: Rough Canyon can be done as an out-and-back or, for the full 5 miles, as a loop.  Follow the canyon up and around, over and across boulders and pools of water to its end and then look for the easy to see trail on your left. This will take you to the Tabeguache Trail.  Go left and follow it back to the parking lot.  The steady climb on the Taeguache Trail is tiring, but it levels out after about a mile.

places.name: Marshall Mesa Area
places.directions: From Broadway & Baseline in Boulder, travel south on Hghwy 93 towards Golden. After 4 miles you will turn left and park at the lot just to the east of 93. The trail head is at the corner of 93 and 170 (Eldorado Springs Drive/Marshall Mesa Drive).

activities.name: Marshall Mesa/Community Ditch
activities.description: Marshall Mesa Trail connects to the Community Ditch Trail and a loop hike can be taken combining these two trails. Self-guided interpretive signs about the coal mining and geologic history of the Marshall area are located along this trail. Community Ditch Trail provides access to the south to the Greenbelt Plateau Trail and to the west to the Doudy Draw area. Birds of prey are frequently sighted in this area. Coyotes and mule deer are common. There is a large prairie dog town near the trailhead.

places.name: Summit Cove/soda Creek Loop
places.directions: Take I70 west of Denver to Silverthorne south on hwy.6  to Swan Mountain Road right, first left on Cove Blvd. Right at Soda Creek on Royalcoachman Blvd.  Left on Forest Glen park at Whispering Pines Trailhead on the right.

activities.name: Summit Cove/Soda Creek Loop
activities.description: Summit Cove/Soda Creek Loop is a beautiful 15 mile loop trail. It takes you over smooth singletrack that winds through dense forests and then it opens up into scenic meadows that allow you to take in the stunning mountain views that surround you.  This is a multi-use trail so please share the trail!

places.name: CDT CO42: Buffalo Pass to North Lake
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO42: Buffalo Pass to North Lake
activities.description: The CDT runs 20.7 miles from Buffalo Pass to North Lake. Along the way, the trail passes Mount Ethel and The Dome.

places.name: Ridgway State Park
places.directions: Take U.S. 550 SOUTH of Montrose for 22 miles to the park entrance, on the right (west) side of the road. NORTH of Ridgway on 550 4 miles to the park entrance, on the left (west) side of the road.
places.description: Mountain scenery mingles with magnificent campgrounds at Ridgway State Park.  Modern, universally-accessible recreation areas and the five-mile long reservoir make memorable days and nights.

activities.name: Ridgway State Park
activities.description: Only 15 miles from the town of Ouray, Ridgway's great outdoors - the "Switzerland of America" - welcomes those from near and far. Seven miles of trails connect the north and south ends of the park.  About three miles of universally-accessible concrete trails and 11 miles of natural surface trails enable visitors to enjoy the scenery yet remain within easy distance of park facilities.   All trails are open and in good condition. There are 14 miles of trail, open for hiking, biking and general access around the park. The Cookie Tree trail has some slight erosion on the west side of the trail (along the reservoir shoreline) due to the high water level; practice caution, the hazard is clearly marked. All other trails are in great condition. Trail maps are available at our Visitor Center. Enjoy!

places.name: Kannah Creek Trail
places.directions: Take Hwy 50 south from Grand Junction for 12 miles; turn left onto Kannah Creek road (sign for Land's end) go 2.7 miles and turn right and right again to continue on Kannah Creek road.  After 6.7 turn right into a parking area just before a bridge and creek crossing.

activities.name: Kannah Creek Trail
activities.description: The Kannah Creek trail climbs almost 8 miles to Carson Lake on the Grand Mesa.  It is an out-and-back trail that gains 4,000 ft of elevation gradually.  Scenic with few fellow hikers. This trail contains many creek crossing so consideration should include spring run-off. Since the trail parallels Kannah Creek for the entire distance, fishing is available at almost any time. This trail also offers a scenic view, especially along the upper section as it looks down into the Kannah Creek Basin.

places.name: Frontside
places.directions: This ride will start from the 18 Road TH parking area.

activities.name: Frontside
activities.description: 22 mile hiking trail located near Fruita, Colorado

places.name: Troy Built Trail
places.directions: From Interstate 70 take the Mack exit 11. Turn south and 1/2 mi.  will be TH parking.

activities.name: Troy Built Trail
activities.description: Troy Built Trail is an 8 mile out-and-back trail on rocky trails traversing the desert terrain. The trail climbs up canyon walls and looks over the famous Colorado River. This trail is part of the Kokopelli Trail System. This is a multi-use trail so please share the path.

places.name: Cross Mtn. Trail
places.directions: From exit #116 on I-70 take Hwy 82 some 38 miles to Brushcreek Rd (R) which takes you to Snowmass Village. (approx 5.5 miles) There are numerous parking options once you get there.  From Base Village, there are a few ways to ascend to this trail.

activities.name: Cross Mountain
activities.description: Cross Mtn. Trail is mainly a connector trail that can be hiked from either the west or the east side. The trail ranges between 10,400-11,000 feet in elevation, and winds through scenic dense forests. It's one of the higher trails on the mountain, and it does have lift access if wanted. This is a multi-use trail so please be aware of mountain bikers.

places.name: Stagecoach State Park
places.directions: North from I-70: Take the Wolcott Exit onto HWY 131 for 50 miles, turn right on County Road 14 for 6 miles.
places.description: Stagecoach State Park sets the stage for great recreation in the lush Yampa Valley by Steamboat Springs. Vistas and views are backdrops to the 820-acre reservoir providing renown lake and river fishing.

activities.name: Stagecoach
activities.description: Stagecoach is part of the actual trail used by the stage line between Grand Junction and Grand Valley. This trail will take you through DeBeque Canyon and along the Colorado River, highlighting some stunning views! The trail can get pretty rough and rocky in parts, but the views make it all worth it!

places.name: Berry Creek Loop
places.directions: From I-70 Exit 163 go south on Beard Creek road up the hill going west.  Just past Shaw Cancer Center make right onto Moonridge Dr. and left into Berry Creek access area (park on right).

activities.name: Berry Creek Loop
activities.description: Berry Creek Loop features is a nice little fireroad/doubletrack hike that takes you through some beautiful juniper and sage scrub. The trail overlooks the surrounding mountains and valleys, a great reward for a fairly easy hike!

places.name: Rabbit Mountain Loop
places.directions: From Boulder, CO.  go north on Highway 36 to Lyons, there will be a light here and you can only go left or right, go right(East) on Highway 66 for about 1 mile.  Turn left on 53rd street, there should be a sign here for Rabbit Mountain open space.  go almost 3 miles and you will see the parking lot on the right.

activities.name: Rabbit Mountain Loop
activities.description: Whether hoping to spot a large raptor in search of prey or a gorgeous view of the Continental Divide, look no further than Rabbit Mountain. Located between Lyons and Longmont, the rich cultural and natural history of Rabbit Mountain is easily accessible to bikers, hikers, and equestrians.

places.name: Mica Mine
places.directions: Drive up Little Park Road until you see a sign on the left for the Bangs Canyon Recreation area.  (5  miles)

activities.name: Mica Mine
activities.description: The Mica Mine trail is 2.6 miles RT and is fairly easy.  It can be hiked by those as young as 4.  It's a great hike through Ladder Canyon to an old Mica Mine site.

places.name: Wheeler Loop
