places.directions: Take I-70 west of Denver to the second Frisco exit #201 East on Main st. to Second Av. turn right follow 2nd av. across bikepath and park in parking lot.

activities.name: Wheeler Loop
activities.description: Wheeler Loop is a must hike if you're in the Breckenridge area. This hike will take you up on a steep climb until you reach the ridgeline. You'll keep hiking along mountain ridges and the views are incredible! The 5.5 mile steep climb at the beginning will seem like it was nothing because of these views!

places.name: Reno / Flag / Bear / Deadman
places.directions: From Colorado Highway 135, take the Cement Creek Road (FS 740) east to the Deadman Gulch Trailhead, about seven miles .  Cement Creek Road is about seven miles south of Crested Butte.

activities.name: Reno / Flag / Bear / Deadman
activities.description: The Reno, Flag, Bear, and Deadman trails are some of the best singletrack trails in Crested Butte! They offer gorgeous views of the surrounding mountains, high alpine meadows, and deep Colorado forests.

places.name: Vail Mountain
places.directions: Exit Vail from I-70 and follow signs to the Vail Village Parking Lot.

activities.name: Vail Mountain
activities.description: In the off-season, Vail Mountain opens it's trails up to hikers and mountain bikers. There are over 25 miles of beautiful mountainside trails, and some even reach up to the summit.

places.name: North Table Mountain
places.directions: From Golden, take CO-93 north toward Boulder. Parking area is just outside Golden on the right side of Hwy 93 and is well marked.

activities.name: North Table Mountain
activities.description: Mostly exposed hiking trails but you'll find a few hidden gems here including a (seasonal?) waterfall. Tremendous views and interesting geology as the trail winds around the sides of the mesa.

places.name: Red Mountain Trail
places.directions: Accessible two ways, but you have to do some hiking on the Paul Intemann Memorial Trail to get to it.In Manitou, take Pawnee St. up until it becomes a dirt road.  Right after you'll see the Paul Intemann trailhead.  Or, take Ruxton up until you would veer off to the right to go to the Incline and the Cog Railroad.  The Intemann trailhead is on the left hand side of the street.

activities.name: Red Mountain Trail
activities.description: This is a 1.3 mile climb to the top, with the same mileage coming back down (obviously.)

places.name: Peaks Trail
places.directions: Go to the end of 2nd Ave off Main St in Frisco, or go to Peak 8 at Breckenridge Ski Resort

activities.name: Peaks Trail
activities.description: This is a one way trail that starts from either the town of Frisco or Breckenridge. The trail climbs in and out of numerous drainages for its' entire length staying mostly in the lodgepole pine forest along with some aspen, spruce and fir forests. Most of the lodgepole pine trees are of the same age and provide ground cover and/or forage for wildlife in the area. You will cross some small clearings which were harvested in 1988. These trees were cut to increase the wildlife habitat and to improve the health of the forest by creating age and species diversity, thereby reducing the fire danger.  Since the grade from Breckenridge toward Frisco is generally downhill, many people travel this direction and ride the free Summit Stage Bus back to Breckenridge.

places.name: Northwest Passage / Tipperary / Spruce Creek / Flume
places.directions: There are many places you can access this loop so feel free to pick up the trail wherever is most convenient for you.  From the town of Fraser, go out the St. Louis Creek Road approximately 2-3 miles.  You will see Forest Service signs on the right side of the road immediately past the trail crossing.  This is the bottom of Northwest Passage (on the right, going to the Northwest) and the end of Creekside (from the left to the south).

activities.name: Northwest Passage / Tipperary / Spruce Creek / Flume
activities.description: This 15 mile loop is basically a beautiful and relaxing walk in the woods. Enjoy hiking on old reclaimed forest roads, and take in the secluded nature that surrounds you. Every once in awhile you'll catch a glimpse of the surrounding mountains! These trails are open to mountain bikers as well, so please share the trail.

places.name: Killpecker
places.directions: Take US 287 north from Fort Collins, CO or south from Laramie, WY to Red Feather Lakes Road.  Go west 24-25 miles to Deadman Road.  Turn left on Deadman Rd. go another 6-7 miles and the Killpecker Trail parking will be on your left (south).

activities.name: Killpecker
activities.description: The trail leads through a pine forest along Killpecker Creek crossing the stream twice before meeting Forest Road 300, Killpecker Road. The trail resumes south of the road about 100 yards to the east. Forest Road 300 intersects the trail twice again before the trail crests just northwest of Middle Bald Mountain then descends to end at Forest Road 517, Elkhorn Creek/Bald Mountain. The south end of North Lone Pine Trail (#953) can be accessed by going approximately a ½-mile east on road 517.  Establishing a shuttle for the 3-mile distance between the Killpecker and North Lone Pine trailheads on Deadman Road may facilitate a loop hiking route using both trails, although motorized vehicles are not allowed on North Lone Pine trail. Killpecker trailhead accommodates approximately 3 vehicles.

places.name: ROCK ISLAND REGIONAL TRAIL
places.directions: Parallel to Highway 24 between Falcon and Ramah.
places.description: The 23-mile Rock Island Regional Trail runs parallel to Highway 24 between Falcon and Ramah and is part of the America the Beautiful Trail.  Nine miles of the trail was constructed on the former Chicago an Rock Island Railroad Line between Falcon and Peyton.  Excellent views of several landmarks are visible from the trail including Pikes Peak, Rampart Range, Rattlesnake Buttes at Homestead Ranch Regional Park, Spanish Peaks, West Mountains, and the Sange de Cristo mountain range.  Opportunities for wildlife observation are abundant. Picnic tables are located at the Falcon Trailhead, and benches are polaced at regular intervals along the trail corridor.

activities.name: ROCK ISLAND REGIONAL TRAIL
activities.description: The 23-mile Rock Island Regional Trail runs parallel to Highway 24 between Falcon and Ramah and is part of the America the Beautiful Trail.  Nine miles of the trail was constructed on the former Chicago an Rock Island Railroad Line between Falcon and Peyton.  Excellent views of several landmarks are visible from the trail including Pikes Peak, Rampart Range, Rattlesnake Buttes at Homestead Ranch Regional Park, Spanish Peaks, West Mountains, and the Sange de Cristo mountain range.  Opportunities for wildlife observation are abundant. Picnic tables are located at the Falcon Trailhead, and benches are polaced at regular intervals along the trail corridor.

places.name: Gregory Canyon / Chautauqua
places.directions: From Boulder, take Broadway south to Baseline. Turn right (west) onto Baseline and look for the Chautauqua ranger station / trailhead area on the left after about a mile.

activities.name: Gregory Canyon / Chautauqua
activities.description: Dozens of trails to choose from, most accessible from the grounds of the Chautauqua National Historic Landmark. We hiked a 2 mile loop combining McClintock and Enchanted Mesa trails. Open valley sections, forested trails, mild to steep climbs, views, rocks - you name it, this trail system has it all. Super convenient to Boulder and University of Colorado.

places.name: Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve
places.directions: From Denver, Colorado Springs, or Pueblo, the most common route is south on I-25 to Walsenburg, west on US 160, north on State Highway 150. For a more mountainous drive from Denver (same mileage as the I-25 route), you may also take US 285 south, then State Highway 17 south, then County Lane 6 east from Mosca. Source: National Park Service

activities.name: Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve
activities.description: The tallest dunes in North America are the centerpiece in a diverse landscape of grasslands, wetlands, conifer and aspen forests, alpine lakes, and tundra.  Explore anything from dune trails, where you can climb the "high dune," to forested trails under the aspens and evergreens, to alpine trails, and back down to trails that wind through grasslands, shrublands, and wetlands! Great Sand Dunes really does have it all!

places.name: South Valley Park
places.directions: From the metro area, travel west on C-470 and exit southbound on Ken Caryl Avenue. Turn left onto South Valley Road to the park's north parking area. Alternately, from South Platte Canyon Road (S. Wadsworth and C-470) take Deer Creek Canyon Road west to the smaller, south parking area.

activities.name: South Valley Park
activities.description: Dramatic red sandstone spires. Stunning views of craggy outcroppings. Pleasant trails suited to beginning mountain bikers and hikers who prefer more level terrain. A diversity of trails offer quiet refuge from the tempo of the neighboring suburbs and criss-cross the eastern half of South Valley Park. The Swallow Trail is hiker-only.

places.name: Flying J Ranch
places.directions: From Denver, head south on Hwy 285 to Hwy 73 in Conifer.  Head north on Hwy 73 for 1 mile to the parking area on the left at the first entrance.  Ride the connector trail up to the main loop.

activities.name: Flying J Ranch
activities.description: This is a very easy, very flat 2 mile loop. It does pass through some pretty forests, though.

places.name: CDT CO30: Argentine Pass to Herman Gulch
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO30: Argentine Pass to Herman Gulch
activities.description: Section 30 of the CDT trail in Colorado runs for 16.7 miles form Argentine Pass to Herman Gulch Trailhead at US Hwy 6. Along the way, the trail passes Decatur Mountain, Ruby Mountain, Argentine Peak, Mount Edwards, Gray's Peak (14,270 ft.), Torrey's Peak (14,267 ft.), Kelso Mountain, and US Hwy 6. Unlike most of the mountain peaks where the CDT skirts below the actual top of the mountain, the CDT actually reaches the summits of Mount Edwards and Gray's Peak, a 14er.

places.name: Limbaugh Canyon (715)
places.directions: take the monument palmer lake exit and head west, drive through downtown monument and over the train tracks. take a left at the stop sign, then take the right on to mt herman road. drive until you see the parking lot on the left hand side. park and ride the trail system over to 715 or take the road that splits the area in half unitl you find 715 on your left.

activities.name: Limbaugh Canyon (715)
activities.description: Limbaugh Canyon (715) is a 25 mile hiking trail in Monument, Colorado.

places.name: Flatirons Vista
places.directions: From Boulder, head south on 93. After you pass Highway 128, turn right into the trailhead parking lot (if your vehicle isn't registered in Boulder county, you're supposed to pay a fee; ignore at your own risk!). You can also take 93 north out of Golden to get here.

activities.name: Flatirons Vista
activities.description: 4 mile hiking trail located near Boulder, Colorado

places.name: South Shore Lake Pueblo
places.directions: Take Colorado 96 west of Pueblo.  Trail starts 1/4 mile after second exit to Lake Pueblo State Park.  At the top of the hill there is a turn off and a red gate.  Trail maps are usually available on a post.

activities.name: South Shore Lake Pueblo
activities.description: These trails are gorgeous! They follow the rims of the canyons offering stunning views of Lake Pueblo, Pikes Peak, and the Front Range. These trails are perfect for a great workout, and keep your eye out for some wildlife! Please remember to share the path!

places.name: Buckhorn Loop
places.directions: From Colorado Springs go west and get on Cheyenne Canyon Rd.  Follow this up through the canyon past Helen Hunt Falls to the large dirt parking lot (This is High Drive parking lot).  The trail begins on the dirt road at the back corner of the parking lot at the gate that restricts cars from access.

activities.name: Buckhorn Loop
activities.description: Buckhorn Loop (Captain Jack's Frontside) features a 5 mile loop trail near Colorado Springs. The trail winds through deep forests and also provides stunning views of the mountains nearby.  This trail is mainly used as a mountain bike trail so please practice caution.

places.name: Praeter Ridge Trail
places.directions: From the main park entrance, drive approximately 4 miles to the Morefield Campground area.

activities.name: Praeter Ridge Trail
activities.description: This trail is a 7.8 mile loop that starts and ends in the Morefield Campground area. The trail takes you along a ridge until you reach the top of the mountain. From the top you get stunning views of the surrounding area.

places.name: CDT CO38: Willow Creek Pass to Troublesome Pass
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO38: Willow Creek Pass to Troublesome Pass
activities.description: Section 38 of the CDT in Colorado runs 11.6 miles from Willow Creek Pass on Hwy 125 to Troublesome Pass. Along the way, the trail passes Haystack Mountain.

places.name: Colorado Trail / Morrison Creek (Lunar Loop)
places.directions: From Colorado Springs, take US 24 to Woodland Park.  Turn right onto CO 67 and go to  Deckers.  Continue straight onto CO 126 approximately 15 miles.  Turn left onto road 550.   Parking lot is on the right.  There is a $4 daily use fee.

activities.name: Colorado Trail / Morrison Creek (Lunar Loop)
activities.description: This section of the trail can be turned into a loop. It climbs a total of about 800 feet, leaving the ascent pretty gradual. You'll hike through a large burn area which leaves you looking out over the beautiful mountainside.  Most of the Colorado Trail is multi-use so please be on the lookout for mountain bikers.

places.name: Wathen Trail
places.directions: From I-25 traveling north from Denver to Fort Collins, take the E. Harmony exit (west) and travel for 3-4 miles until you come to South Taft.  Turn right on So. Taft and drive a short distance until you intersect 38E.  Turn left on 38E and drive up around Horsetooth Lake until you come to Horsetooth Park.  Park in the parking lot on the right, but make sure you have a day pass.

activities.name: Waltham Trail
activities.description: Waltham Trail is a tough 12 mile trail that connects with a network of other trails. The trail traverses through the desert terrain, over bluffs, and it climbs rocky paths to keep your heart rate up.  This is a multi-use trail so please share the path.

places.name: Mesa Verde National Park
places.directions: Mesa Verde National Park is in Southwestern Colorado. The Mesa Verde Headquarters is a one-hour drive from Cortez, Colorado, heading east on Highway 160 to the park turnoff, and a 1.5 hour drive from Durango, Colorado, heading west on Highway 160 to the park turnoff.Source: National Park Service

activities.name: Mesa Verde National Park
activities.description: Hiking in Mesa Verde National Park is restricted and allowed only on designated trails. Visitors may not enter cliff dwellings unless accompanied by a uniformed park ranger. However there are several trails that total 20 miles within the park. Source: National Park Service

places.name: Memmen Ridge Open Space
places.directions: Memmen  Ridge DirectionsDirections from I-25:1. Take the Wolfensberger Rd/ Wilcox St exit, Exit 1822.Turn east at the ramp and follow Wilcox St for approx. 0.6 miles3.Turn left at 2nd St and follow for 0.3 miles.4.Turn right at Gilbert St and follow for 0.1 miles.5.Turn left at South St then turn right at Oman Road.6. Trailhead parking lot will be on your left.

activities.name: Memmen Ridge Open Space
activities.description: This area provides a quick escape into forested open space from nearby Downtown Castle Rock. The 43-acre parcel is located south of South Street Elementary School and can be accessed from a paved trail at Oman Road. The willows and cattails in the riparian area quickly change to a mature ponderosa pine forest on the ridge's north-facing slope. A short trip to the top of this ridge can provide views of the southern areas of Town.

places.name: Devil's Canyon Hiking Area
places.directions: From I-70 West take the Fruita exit and turn left (south).  Cross the Colorado River and turn right onto King's View Court.  This will turn into a gravel/dirt road.  The sign and parking area for Devil's Canyon will become visible on the left after a mile at the most.

activities.name: Devil's Canyon Hiking Area
activities.description: Devil's Canyon is not just one hiking trail - it's 2 canyons and a myriad of possibilities all in one.  Unlike a lot of the trails in the Fruita/Grand Junction area, the Devil's Canyon trails are for horses and people only.  If you aren't a fan of dodging mountain or dirt bikers, this is the place to go.  Most people allow their dogs to run off-leash here as well.  Maps are available near the beginning of the trail area and should be used!  The Devil's Canyon side has about 6 different trails (D1-D6) that loop, connect and intersect through washes, and around canyon walls.  The Kodel Canyon side has even more trails (K1-K8?) that also intersect, mostly on top of a large ridge. The trails are all well marked, so if you've got a map you'll have no trouble exploring here.  There are caves to peek in to, old miner cabins to photograph and views galore.  A popular area, you'll never be alone out here, but you'll definitely enjoy the hike.

places.name: Castlewood Canyon State Park
places.directions: To reach the main entrance of Castlewood Canyon State Park, take I-25 to Castle Rock, exit onto Founders Parkway eastbound. Take Founders Parkway to Hwy 86, go east on Hwy 86 four miles to Franktown. Turn South on Hwy 83 (S. Parker Rd) and go five miles south to the main park entrance.
places.description: Castlewood Canyon State Park is a Colorado state park near Franktown, Colorado. The park protects a unique part of Colorado's history (the Castlewood Canyon Dam).

activities.name: Castlewood Canyon State Park
activities.description: Nature lovers and groups enjoy environmental diversity on several hiking trails ranging from mild to moderate. The trails range from .5 to 4 miles and can be combined for longer journeys.  The winding Cherry Creek flowing along the canyon floor provides wonderful rest stops.  Pets, on a leash, are welcome on most trails, except the new East Canyon Preservation Area trail.

places.name: Government Trail
places.directions: From I-70 take exit #116 to HWY 82. South on 82 for 35+ miles to Brushcreek Rd. Right or south on Brushcreek for approx. 5.5 miles to a split in the road, go right onto Divide Rd. and in over a mile a parking area on leftish.

activities.name: Government/Brush Creek
activities.description: The trail begins a short distance up Maroon Creek Road at Islen Park behind the tennis courts.  It continues across the river to Buttermilk Mountain.  The total trip of 7 miles (one way) to Snowmass Village winds through wooded areas and meadows.  This is a pleasant hike after a steep beginning.   Hikers MUST be careful to stay on the trail as it crosses private property.  Miles one way: 6.8.  Elevation: 9,400 ft. - 11,400 ft. (EASY - LONG)

places.name: Chasm Lake
places.directions: Head South from Estes Park on Highway 7 for 9.2 miles. Turn right onto Longs Peak Road. This road ends at the Longs Peak Trailhead. If you don't get here early though, you may have to park a long ways away.

activities.name: Chasm Lake
activities.description: The trail is well labeled and easy to find due to the traffic it receives. From the trailhead begin by following the route towards Longs Peak. Soon after breaking treeline you will come to an intersection where the Longs Peak trail goes right and the Chasm Lake trail goes left. There is a sign here labeling the trail for Chasm lake. (There is also a restroom here) Take this trail the rest of the way to Chasm Lake.

places.name: Pipeline Trail
places.directions: Look up the directions to the Jones Park trail.  They share the same trailhead.  From where you park your shuttle vehicle (if you shuttled--highly recommended), instead of taking trail 701 to the left, go straight down trail 668--this is the pipeline trail.

activities.name: Pipeline Trail
activities.description: Pipeline Trail is a 6 mile out-and-back trail near the city of Colorado Springs. This trail is pretty rocky in parts and it winds through dense forests, ever once in awhile opening up into a aspen covered field. You can sneak in some views of the surrounding mountains when the tree cover breaks.  Please share the path with mountain bikers and dirt bikers.

places.name: CDT CO27: Copper Mountain to Gold Hill
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO27: Copper Mountain to Gold Hill
activities.description: The CDT runs for 12.6 miles from Copper Mountain to Gold Hill Trailhead on Hwy 9. Along the way, the trail passes Peak 8, Peak 4, and Tenmile Peak.

places.name: Eldorado Canyon State Park
places.directions: According to parks.state.co.us, "Eldorado Canyon State Park is located about five miles southwest of Boulder. Take Broadway / State Highway 93 south from Boulder, turn west (right) onto Colorado 170 and then continue about three miles to the town of Eldorado Springs. Highway 170 dead-ends at the town and a dirt road continues. The park is located at the end of the dirt road on the left. Our book store / visitor's center is one mile west from the park's entrance. "
places.description:
Eldorado Canyon State Park is a fantastic location full of sandstone cliffs, flowing creeks, picturesque mountains and the well known Eldo's golden cliffs. There are numerous (500 hundred plus) rock climbing options for many levels of skill. The park also offers several  trails of various skill levels from simple to difficult, all equally beautiful.  

Picnicking, fishing, hiking, rock climbing, and cross-country skiing are all popular activities here. Camping is also offered near the park.

activities.name: Eldorado Canyon State Park
activities.description: Eldorado Canyon State Park just outside of Boulder, Colorado offers over 11 miles of hiking trails. The specific trails in the park are the Eldorado Canyon Trail, Rattlesnake Gulch, Fowler Trail, Streamside Trail, and Crescent Meadows. These trails offer up gorgeous views of the canyon, some of the streams, and the surrounding mountains. They vary in difficulty greatly depending on which trail you choose.  In addition to hiking, Eldorado Canyon is a very popular destination for Bouldering and Rock Climbing with over 500 technical rock climbing routes. Several of the trails are also open to mountain biking.

places.name: Santa Fe Trail
places.directions: Numerous parking areas for this trail.  1. Take Woodmen Rd. West from I-25.  After the first bridge over the creek, turn right into the parking lot.  The trail goes north or south from here.  2. Access from the Air Force Academy is also possible via the north and south entrances.

activities.name: Santa Fe Trail
activities.description: Santa Fe Trail takes you through the communities of Palmer Lake and Monument, and then it turns onto the Air Force Academy territory. The trail is a really nice, wide multi-use trail that makes for an easy hike.  Please share the trail with other users.

places.name: Prime Cut
places.directions: Take 17.5 from town to N 3/10 road and hang a right. Turn left on 18 road and go until the pavement runs out, then stay on the dirt road for 4.3 miles and the trailhead is on the left. From the trailhead, ride on up the dirt road and take the jeep road on the right for about 100 yards down a hill, then  hit the singletrack going back to the left.

activities.name: Prime Cut
activities.description: Prime Cut is 3 miles of climbing up singletrack, rocky steps, and boulders. It can be used as an out-and-back or you can connect to the other network of trails, like Joe's Ridge, to make it into a loop.  Please note that these trails are mainly used as mountain bike trails and there is a high amount of bike traffic in the area.

places.name: Raccoon
places.directions: From GoldenTake Highway 93 north from Golden one mile to Golden Gate Canyon Road. Turn left and continue for 13 miles to the park. From the Denver Area using Golden Gate Canyon RdFollow I-70 west to exit 265 for highway 58. Take highway 58 west to highway 93. Turn right (north) on highway 93 for approximately 1 mile to Golden Gate Canyon road. Turn left and follow Golden Gate Canyon road 13 miles to the Visitor Center. The campground is approximately 5 miles from the Visitor Center( in the summer when Mountain Base Rd is open. In winter continue on Hwy 46 West 3 mi to Hwy 119 go north on Hwy 119 4mi to mile marker 15.5 approximately and look for Gap Rd on your right). RVs or vehicles towing large trailers must continue west to Hwy 119 all seasons. From BoulderTake highway 93 south to Golden Gate Canyon road. Turn right and follow Golden Gate Canyon road 13 miles to the Visitor Center. The campground is approximately 5 miles from the Visitor Center (in summer when Mountain Base Rd is open). RVs or vehicles towing large trailers must continue west on Hwy 46 to Hwy 119 all seasons. Turn north onto 119, at mile marker approx 15.5 turn right on Gap Road to access Reverend's Ridge and Aspen Meadow campgrounds.

activities.name: Raccoon
activities.description: Located in Golden Gate Canyon State Park, the Raccoon loop trail starts behind the office at the campground. It starts at an elevation of over 9,000 feet and meanders through aspen trees, blue spruce, and douglas firs. The climax of the trail is when you reach Panorama Point which provides excellent views of the Continental Divide.

places.name: Red Rocks
places.directions: See Google Maps. There are many trailheads in the area, however, including at the Red Rocks Amphitheater.

activities.name: Red Rocks
activities.description: The Red Rocks area, located around the Red Rocks Amphitheater, is a trail network that winds up the mountain sides above the Hogback and the city of Denver, and amongst the incredible red rock formations. These trails offer gorgeous views of the surrounding area and the unique rock formations, making for very entertaining hiking.

places.name: Greenland Open Space
places.directions: Coming from Monument Colorado, head North on I-25.  About 5-6 miles North of Monument take exit 167.  Turn left (west) and go under the interstate.  You will now be on Greenland Rd.  Follow this road for about 1 mile and you will reach the destination.  About .5 miles into the 1 mile road the road will make a hard left turn toward the south.  The road will run into the Greenland Open Space.

activities.name: Greenland Open Space
activities.description: Part of the Colorado Front Range Trail, the lower trail joins into the Old Territorial Road, connecting the old Greenland Townsite to Palmer Lake. The 11-mile trail system is within over 3,000 acres of Greenland Open Space. The trail passes through native grasslands, by ponds, through rolling Gambel oak hills and skirts ponderosa pine forests. There are beautiful views of Greenland open space, buttes and Pikes Peak.

places.name: Jackson Lake State Park
places.directions: From the U.S. 34/I-76 interchange, take Colorado Highway 39 north for 7.25 miles through Goodrich, then go west on Y5 (follow the paved road) for 2.5 miles.
places.description: This park is an "Oasis in the Plains," for swimming, boating, fishing and waterskiing. But that's not all...

activities.name: Jackson Lake State Park
activities.description: Prairie Wetland Nature Trail is a 1/4 mile, self-guided trail and is located north of Cove Campground. There is also a 1.5 mile trail located between the Visitor Center north to Northview Campground. A trail is also located on the south side of the park from the south swimbeach to Cottonwood day-use picnic area. Folks also enjoy walking along the shoreline or along park roadways.

places.name: Indian (1300)
places.directions: Take highway 12 south thru La Veta; on the south side of town you will find Forest Road 421 heading west into the mountains.  Take that road about eight miles or so till you find the obvious trailhead and parking area.

activities.name: Indian (1300)
activities.description: The Indian Creek Trail #1300 trailhead is located on the north side of the Bear Lake Campground. This trailhead is a multi user trail system and accesses 23 miles of motorized trails available for ATV, motorcycle, bicycle, foot and horse use. Follow these scenic ATV trails through the thick mountain forests and overlook the beautiful Spanish Peaks across in the east and the high Sangre de Cristos in the southwest. Remember to share the trail!

places.name: Penitente Canyon
places.directions: From Del Norte travel North on HWY 112 for aproximately 5 miles then turn left onto 33 (dirt road) follow thos for apprximatly 10 miles. There will be signs for the park on the left side of the road. There are 2 pulloffs for the park go to the second road and find a place to park. We parked at the intersection and biked in, but you can drive up the road to some camoing areas to park closer to the trailhead.

activities.name: Penitente Canyon
activities.description: Penitente Canyon offers gorgeous desert landscape with impressive sandstone cliffs. It is a true rock climbing destination, so don't expect to have the place all to yourself!

places.name: CDT CO29: Georgia Pass to Argentine Pass
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO29: Georgia Pass to Argentine Pass
activities.description: The CDT runs for 18.3 miles from Georgia Pass to Argentine Pass. Along the way, the trail passes Santa Fe Peak and Revenue Mountain.

places.name: CDT CO31: Herman Gulch to Berthoud Pass
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO31: Herman Gulch to Berthoud Pass
activities.description: Section 31 of the CDT in Colorado runs for 20.4 miles from Herman Gulch to Berthoud Pass on US Hwy 40. Along the way, the trail passes Mount Bethel, Mount Parnassus, Woods Mountain, The Citadel, Pettingell Peak, Hassell Peak, Harrison Mountain, Vasquez Peak, and Stanley Mountain.

places.name: Meyers Homestead Trail
places.directions: From Boulder at the intersection of Broadway and Baseline, go 7.5 miles west on Baseline (which winds and turns all over up the mountains), and go right into the Meyers Gulch trailhead parking lot.

activities.name: Meyers Homestead Trail
activities.description: Meyers Homestead Trail is part of the Walker Ranch Open Space, about 9 miles out of Boulder. This out-and-back trail has beautiful foliage and you're likely to see a herd of elk grazing nearby. There are also interpretive signs along the trail that teach hikers about local history and ecology.

places.name: CDT CO12: Spring Creek Pass Trailhead to San Luis Pass
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO12: Spring Creek Pass Trailhead to San Luis Pass
activities.description: The CDT runs for 14.3 miles from Spring Creek Pass to San Luis Pass. Along the way it passes Gain Snow Mesa, Baldy no es Cinco, and Baldy.

places.name: Heil Valley Ranch
places.directions: From Boulder, go North on Highway 36 to Lefthand Canyon Road, turn left here.  Go about .5 mile to Geer Canyon Road, turn right here.  Go about 1 mile to parking lot.

activities.name: Heil Valley Ranch
activities.description: With beautiful hanging valleys, picturesque vistas, and forest meadows that seem to cling to the sky, Heil Valley Ranch is a playground for wildlife. It only takes one visit to this 5,020-acre property to turn a sedentary person into an outdoor enthusiast. There are 5 trails located here ranging from easy to moderate with the longest trail topping out at 5.2 miles. Dogs are not allowed due to wildlife concerns.

places.name: Ute Valley Park
places.directions: From I-25, exit at Woodmen Rd.  Go West.  Woodmen becomes Rockrimmon Rd.  Follow Rockrimmon Rd. approximately 1.5 miles.  Turn right onto Vindicator.  Go approximately 3/4 mile.  Parking lot on the left.

activities.name: Ute Valley Park
activities.description: Ute Valley Park has 8 miles of trails that wind through desert terrain. Most of these trails are wide and are fairly easy to hike. You'll have plenty of chances to view the stunning scenery that surrounds the park. These trails are multi-use, so please share the path.

places.name: Doubletop Trail / #405
places.directions: Access via Block & Tackle Trail 545 off Cement Creek Rd. Also accessible via Caves Trail 409 further south on Cement Creek Rd.

activities.name: Doubletop Trail / #405
activities.description: 5 mile hiking trail located near Crested Butte, Colorado

places.name: CDT CO23: South Clear Creek to Halfmoon Creek
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO23: South Clear Creek to Halfmoon Creek
activities.description: Section 23 of the CDT in Colorado runs 28.2 miles from South Clear Creek to Halfmoon Creek. Along the way, the trail passes the Sheep Gulch Trailhead, Willis Gulch, Middle Mountain, Ervin Peak, Mount Hope, Quail Mountain, Twin Lakes, Hwy 82, and Mount Elbert (elevation 14,433), the highest peak in Colorado and the highest of the Rocky Mountains of North America.

places.name: Eagle Vail Trail
places.directions: Turn off of Highway 6 in Eagle Vail onto Eagle Road.  Follow road past police station and turn right onto Eagle Drive.  Park at the first parking lot on the right, and then bike up Eagle Drive to the Cul de Sac (about 10 minutes).  Singletrack starts here and winds through an aspen grove to the junction with Pauley's Plunge.  Turn right at this junction and ride downhill on the last bit of Pauley's until you reach a footbridge at the golf course.  From here you will see a sign pointing uphill and to the left for the eagle Vail trail.  Continue riding until you filter out onto the road about 3 miles later.  Ride road east along Deer Blvd and Stone Creek Dr until you reach your car at the parking lot on Eagle Dr.

activities.name: Eagle Vail Trail
activities.description: This trail winds through an aspen grove to the junction with Pauley's Plunge.  Turn right at this junction and hike downhill on the last bit of Pauley's until you reach a footbridge at the golf course.  From here you will see a sign pointing uphill and to the left for the eagle Vail trail.  Continue hiking until you filter out onto the road about 3 miles later.  Hike the road east along Deer Blvd and Stone Creek Dr until you reach your car at the parking lot on Eagle Dr.

places.name: Chatfield State Park
places.directions: The main entrance to Chatfield State Park is located one mile south of C-470 on Wadsworth. Make a left into the park from the traffic light (there will be a brown sign for Chatfield State Park).
places.description: Float your boat in the lake, bicycle or hike on a trail that provides scenic views of the neighboring foothills and Platte River valley, camp, ride a horse and even fly a model airplane - all at Chatfield State Park, nestled next to the foothills southwest of Denver.

activities.name: Chatfield State Park
activities.description: A series of trails wind through the Chatfield area and provides the park visitor with an abundance of recreational opportunities. You can take a morning jog, walk through natural areas around the reservoir, leisurely pedal your bicycle through the park or ride a horse into the sunset. Trail maps are available at the park's main entrances.

places.name: FOUNTAIN CREEK REGIONAL TRAIL
places.directions: Fountain Creek Trailheads are located at Willow Springs, Duckwood Active Use Areawith Hanson Nature Park. Access to the trail is also available from the nature trails of the Fountain Creek Nature Center.
places.description: Starting along Fountain Creek at the El Pomar Youth Sports Complex in Colorado Springs, the trail continues south through the Fountain Creek Regional Park.

activities.name: FOUNTAIN CREEK REGIONAL TRAIL
activities.description: Starting along Fountain Creek at the El Pomar Youth Sports Complex in Colorado Springs, the trail continues south through the Fountain Creek Regional Park.

places.name: Green Mountain
places.directions: From I-25, take 6th Ave. west. Drive approximately 6 miles to Kipling. Take Kipling south for 2 miles before taking a right on Alameda. Stay on Alameda for 3 miles until you see a parking area on the right. This trail is part of William Frederick Hayden Park.

activities.name: Green Mountain--William Frederick Hayden Park
activities.description: With more than 2,400 acres of open space, William Frederick Hayden Park on Green Mountain is the second largest park in Lakewood.  The park features a challenging network of multi-use trails. The summit, at 6,800 feet, offers unique and stunning views of the Denver metropolitan area to the east, as well as high mountain peaks to the west.

places.name: Calypso Cascades
places.directions: This trail is located in the Wild Basin region of Rocky Mountain National Park. The nearest town is Allenspark at the southeastern corner of the park. From Allenspark, head north on SR 7. The entrance to the park will be on the left. If you are coming from Estes Park, head south on SR 7. The entrance will be on your right.

activities.name: Calypso Cascades
activities.description: This trail follows a raging stream for 1.8 miles up to the Calypso Cascades waterfall. It is a fairly easy hike gaining 700 ft in elevation. After just 0.3 miles you will meet up with Copeland Falls. Watch the water for long enough and you might see the water ouzel or the American dipper bird.  Along the way you'll be shaded by lots of pine and aspen. This is a nice hike with the relaxing sound of rushing water every step of the way.

places.name: Rattlesnake Gulch
places.directions: It's in Eldorado Canyon State Park.  From Boulder, drive south on CO HWY 93 5 miles to CO HWY 170.  Take this west for 2.5 miles to the entrance to the park.  The trail head is on the south side of the road, a couple of miles into the park.  I park at the lot beyond the trail head, which is where this track is from.

activities.name: Rattlesnake Gulch
activities.description: A moderately difficult trail leading 1.4 miles (one way) past spectacular views of the canyon and eastern plains to the remains of historic Crags hotel, 600 feet above the trailhead. Built in 1908, the hotel was accessed via an inclined railway from the canyon floor until it burned down in 1913.  The trail continues as a .8 mile loop as it travels to a view of the Continental Divide and the railroad tracks, 1,200 feet above the trailhead. The trail is 1.4 miles to the ruins and another .8 mile for the loop, making the total roundtrip distance about 3.6 miles.

places.name: Petroglyph Point Trail
places.directions: Follow the main park road to the Chapin Mesa area and park at the museum.

activities.name: Petroglyph Point Trail
activities.description: A 2.4 mile loop starting at the Spruce Tree House, leading to petroglyphs and stunning canyon scenery.

places.name: Powerline
places.directions: From I-70 exit #116 and take Hwy 82 towards Aspen, around 35 miles. Take Brush Creek Rd. 5 miles to Base Village. Parking is abundant.

activities.name: Powerline
activities.description: Powerline features 3 miles of hiking trails near Snowmass Village, CO.

places.name: Zig Zag
places.directions: Mt Werner Circle to Gondola Square.  Park in the garage.

activities.name: Zig Zag
activities.description: Zig Zag is a 5 mile out-and-back trail at Steamboat Ski Resort. Enjoy a mix of singletrack, doubletrack, and gravel road, which winds up the mountain over rolling hills and along switchbacks. Hike through thick forests, but when the forests break you'll enjoy stunning scenery of the surrounding area.  This is a multi-use trail, so please share the trail.

places.name: Box Canyon Trail
places.directions: From Dinosaur, CO travel west on HWY 40 to HWY 149.  Turn North on HWY 149 and proceed through the entrance station.  Trail is located about 10 miles past the temporary visitor center.

activities.name: Box Canyon Trail
activities.description: Short pleasant hike along a dry stream bed to a small box canyon. Interpretative trail with occasional signs that give local natural and cultural information.

places.name: Garden of the Gods (Ute Trail)
places.directions: From I-25, exit at Garden of the Gods Rd.  Head West of G.O.D.G. Rd. and follow the signs to the visitor's center.  Park here and ride down under the highway into the park.  At the stop signed intersection in the park, trail starts on the left side of the road.  Signs for Ute trail.

activities.name: Garden of the Gods
activities.description: There are numerous trails to hike at Garden of the Gods. Some of them are paved and crowded with tourists, and some of them are narrow singletrack that's more remote.   I have visited many natural places, and Garden of the Gods is close to the top of my lists of most beautiful places of all time! You have to experience the grandeur of these sandstone rocks!  Garden of the Gods is also very popular as a rock climbing and bouldering destination.

places.name: Fountain Creek Nature Center
places.directions: From I-25 Exit 132A, go east on CO 16 to US Hwy. 85, then south one-half mile. Turn west on Cattail Marsh Road to parking area.
places.description: Walk the wetlands, search for great blue herons, and explore Fountain Creek - only 15 minutes south of downtown Colorado Springs! An "oasis on the plains" with ponds marshes, meadows, cottonwood forests, and Fountain Creek, the nature center is attractive to visitors of all ages. The nature center offers a unique look into the Cattail Marsh Wildlife Area and serves as an entry to a variety of discovery experiences. Wetlands nature exhibit feature life in, on and around the water. Other exhibits include plants, wildlife, weather and climate, and the mountain backdrop. Interpretive programs, special events, group tours, and environmental education programs for schools are offered throughout the year.

activities.name: Fountain Creek Nature Center
activities.description: Walk the wetlands, search for great blue herons, and explore Fountain Creek - only 15 minutes south of downtown Colorado Springs! An "oasis on the plains" with ponds marshes, meadows, cottonwood forests, and Fountain Creek, the nature center is attractive to visitors of all ages. The nature center offers a unique look into the Cattail Marsh Wildlife Area and serves as an entry to a variety of discovery experiences. Wetlands nature exhibit feature life in, on and around the water. Other exhibits include plants, wildlife, weather and climate, and the mountain backdrop. Interpretive programs, special events, group tours, and environmental education programs for schools are offered throughout the year.

places.name: Black Forest Section 16 Trail
places.directions: This is not the same place as Black Forest Regional Park.  Just west of the intersection of Burgess & Vollmer roads in Black Forest.

activities.name: Black Forest Section 16 Trail
activities.description: Black Forest Section 16 Trail is a square shaped loop in the Black Forest. It is a gravel path that provides a 4 mile circle with very little elevation change through the beautiful forest.  This area is popular with horseback riders so please practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Joe's Ridge
places.directions: Take 17.5 from town to N 3/10 road and hang a right. Turn left on 18 road and go until the pavement runs out, then stay on the dirt road for 4.3 miles and the trailhead is on the left. If you just want to ride Joe's Ridge, keep going past the first trailhead for about 2 more miles to the upper trailhead and you can ride Joe's Ridge down to the first trailhead, then either take the road back or ride Prime Cut back up. Suggested route: Ride Prime Cut up to the top and the Joe's Ridge back to the first trailhead.

activities.name: Joe's Ridge
activities.description: This 3 mile trail quickly takes you out to a ridge and then descends along the ridge. The trail is open and overlooks the beautiful desert area that encircles the trail. It can be hiked either as an out-and-back or as part of a network of trails.  Please note that these trails are mainly used as mountain bike trails and there is a high amount of bike traffic in the area.

places.name: Snodgrass
places.directions: Head north out of Crested Butte towards the resort, hang a left on Washington Gulch, and  the trail starts a couple miles down on the right.  Snodgrass runs between Washington Gulch and Gothic road, so you could start on either end, or loop it.  If you are riding it as an out and back, park down on Washington so you can do most of the climbing at the beginning.

activities.name: Snodgrass
activities.description: Snodgrass isn't as steep or remote of a trails as many near Crested Butte. The trailhead is just a short drive from town, and it meanders through a beautiful aspen forest as it slowly climbs to the open meadows at the top of the ridge. For such a short little trail, that is close to town, this is really stunning!

places.name: Telegraph Trail System - South
places.directions: The Sale Barn trail head is located across from the Home Depot on US550/160 (S Camino Del Rio) at the Southern end of Durango. There is a sign at the turnoff from the highway onto a frontage road. Pull into the gravel parking lot up the hill on the right.

activities.name: Telegraph Trail System (south)
activities.description: Telegraph Trail System (south) is basically right in downtown Durango, making it a perfect place for a quick getaway! This network of loop trails will take you on switchbacks in and out of scenic canyons and along paths with low-lying desert scrub lining the trail. You'll also hike into wide open fields that showcase the mountains that surround you! These trails are multi-use and very popular with mountain bikers, so please share the trail!

places.name: Buffer Creek
places.directions: Take Vail exit 176. Head West on the North Frontage Rd. Take a Right on Red Sandstone Rd. Follow the road up hill until you see a trailhead parking lot on the left. If it is full continue up hill until you see a dirt road on the left (this is the route on bike as well) You should find parking 3/4 of a mile up the road. Signs say snowmobile parking.

activities.name: Buffer Creek
activities.description: This 14 mile loop trail follows both a dirt road and some singletrack. There's a fairly long climb, but all the work pays off with scenic views of the Gorge Range and Vail Mountain.  This is a multi-use trail and is frequented by mountain bikers so please practice trail etiquette.

places.name: CDT CO13: San Luis Pass to Eddiesville Trailhead
places.directions: While San Luis Pass is the southernmost point, the best place to park is the northern end: lat=38.026633, lon=-106.8344

activities.name: CDT CO13: San Luis Pass to Eddiesville Trailhead
activities.description: The CDT runs for 12.7 miles from San Luis Pass to the Eddiesville Trailhead. Along the way the trail passes Spring Creek, San Luis Peak, Organ Mountain, and Table Mountain.

places.name: Mueller State Park
places.directions: From Colorado Springs, take US 24 West to Woodland Park.  Continue on 24 to Divide, CO.  At the light in Divide, turn left onto State Hwy 67.  The park is about 5 miles on the right.  Costs about $4 to get in or $10 for a campsite.

activities.name: Mueller State Park
activities.description: Mueller State Park's 55 miles of trails provide a 5,000-acre playground for the hiker, mountain biker and wildlife watcher. Visitors are invited to explore the park's natural and historical resources via 55 miles of trails. Trails vary from short, leisurely walks to challenging, full-day hikes. The average elevation in the park is 9,600 feet.  All trails are open to hikers. Mueller has several short trails for the family to enjoy. Each trail ranges in distance from one-half mile to 3-1/3 miles round trip.

places.name: Flowing Park Loop
places.directions: From HWY 65 South turn right onto Land's End Road and then onto Flowing Park Road (#109 - first road on the left).  Follow this road until its end at Flowing Park reservoir.  You'll see a gated area just ahead.  The trail begins there.

activities.name: Flowing Park Loop
activities.description: Flowing Park Loop is a 14 mile hiking trail in Mesa, Colorado.

places.name: Stanley Canyon
places.directions: Trail starts on the US Air Force Academy. From North Gate Dr. continue on Academy Drive, turn right on Pine Drive. Trailhead is at the end of the gravel road on the right of Pine Drive.

activities.name: Stanley Canyon
activities.description: Fairly steep and well traveled hike up to Stanley Reservoir with forest road connection to Rampart Reservoir. Very scenic hike.

places.name: Cherry Creek Lake
places.directions: On the southeast fringe of Denver off I-225/Parker Road.
places.description: Cherry Creek Dam, located at the southeast edge of Denver in Aurora, CO, was the first of the three dams to be built to protect the Denver region from catastrophic South Platte River floodwaters that plagued the area for more than 100 years. Recreational opportunities include camping, fishing, picnicking, an archery/rifle range, a horse stable, nature and bike trails, a marina, and a swimming area. The park is open year-round.

activities.name: Cherry Creek Lake
activities.description: Cherry Creek Dam, located at the southeast edge of Denver in Aurora, CO, was the first of the three dams to be built to protect the Denver region from catastrophic South Platte River floodwaters that plagued the area for more than 100 years. Recreational opportunities include camping, fishing, picnicking, an archery/rifle range, a horse stable, nature and bike trails, a marina, and a swimming area. The park is open year-round.

places.name: Barbour Fork Loop
places.directions: Take I-70 west of Denver to Idaho Springs exit #241 left on Miner Street just past Safeway , left on Soda Creek past the hot springs continue past the dump to the parking lot just before the forest service gate. About 3 miles total from I.S

activities.name: Barbour Fork Loop
activities.description: Barbour Fork Loop is an OHV trail, open to hikers, that mainly winds throughout the wooded forests of the front country. The trail is not particularly scenic because it stays mostly within tree cover, but it's perfect for a walk in the woods. Enjoy the surrounding aspen forests, but be ready for a tough workout, because there are plenty of steep climbs along this trail.

places.name: Alpine Loop
places.directions: The trail is well marked and signposted.  From the car park at the trailhead (+10,000ft) at Eureka head up the trail to Animas Forks.  This about a 3.5 mile steady climb on a decent 4WD trail that takes you up to about +11,000 ft.  About 0.5 miles past Animas Forks you take a right turn following the signs for Cinnamon Pass.  From here the trail climbs more steeply over the next 3 miles to the pass (+12,630ft) with a few difficult rock sections.  Once at the the pass, enjoy the view as you are surrounded by 14,000+ ft peak!!!.  From the pass, the trail descends steeply at first with some rocky sections.  After about 2.5 miles the trail splits (CR 12), stay left.  From here you ride another easy 7.5 miles or so downhill until you reach Co Rd 30.  There are a few turn-offs on the right on the way but just stay left.  Turn left on Co Rd 30. Ride about 8 miles on a decent dirt road where the 30 forks left around Lake San Cristabal.  Ride around the west side of the lake until you reach the 149 turn left and head into Lake City.  You've just completed about 24 miles of downhill with a drop of elevation to around 8,730ft - get ready for the uphill!!  At 1st St turn left, after a few hundred yards, fork left onto Co Rd 20.  There is now about 20 miles of climbing to get the Engineer Pass (+12,800ft).  The road starts off easy so enjoy the first 10 miles as you climb easily (after about 6 miles you pass the turn off to Co Rd 23 on the right).   After about 10 miles you reach a junction (Co Rd 24), here you need to take a left turn and continue on Co Rd 20.  From here the road starts to climb more steeply with rocky and heavily rutted sections.  After about 5 more miles you will reach another junction, stay right on Co Rd 20 and right again after about another mile.  Now the real climb begins about 4 miles from Engineer Pass.  You grind it out to the pass with a few sections that you may have to hike your bike.  At the pass, the road turns to the left and continues to climb (ouch) looping around the side of Engineer Mountain.  Enjoy the view, it's SPECTACULAR.  Continue to climb another 0.5 mile (+150 ft) and then start to descend.  There is a short uphill (downhill all the way after this) and after a mile you come to a junction.  Take a right and follow some switchbacks down another mile where you will pass a trail on the right.  Go straight on for about 0.5 mile to another junction where you turn left.  Carry on for another 2 miles to Animas Forks (passing to trail up to Cinnamon Pass you took earlier after about 1.5 miles).  From Animas Forks, take to trail downhill another 3.5 miles to the trailhead and car park.

activities.name: Alpine Loop
activities.description: 58 mile hiking trail located near Silverton, Colorado

places.name: Betasso Preserve
places.directions: From US36 in Boulder, go west on Canyon Rd approx 4 miles. Past the tunnel, turn right on Sugarloaf Rd. Go about a mile and turn right on Betasso Rd. The trailhead is about 1/2 mile or so on the left.

activities.name: Betasso Preserve
activities.description: A couple loops to choose from with scenery ranging from wooded to open meadows to views of Boulder below. Not too crowded on weekdays and some of the trails are closed to bikes on Wednesdays and Saturdays.

places.name: Ginny Trail
places.directions: Take Harmony Road thru town (exit 265 off I-25) past the Taft Hill Road intersection. At this point Harmony becomes CR 38E.  Continue past Horsetooth reservoir and Horsetooth Mountain Park until you get into Masonville.  Turn left at the Masonville Mercantile (CR27).  Take a quick right (only about 1/2 mile down) on CR 32C - marked for the Bobcat Ridge Natural Area.  Stay left and continue up the road to a large parking area with facilities.  The Ginny Trail starts on the left hand side thru the fence.

activities.name: Ginny Trail
activities.description: Ginny Trail is a 5.4 mile out-and-back hike that climbs 1,500 feet. The trail is open for hiking and mountain biking, but closed to horses. This hike takes you through a major burn area, which provides stunning views of the surrounding area for you! This is a multi-use trail so please share the path with mountain bikers.

places.name: Colorado Trail/ West Jefferson Trail
places.directions: Takw hwy 285 wert of Denver to Krnosha Pass about 20 miles past Baily

activities.name: Colorado Trail/ West Jefferson Trail
activities.description: Start out at Kenosha Pass and follow the Colorado Trail to the West Jefferson Trail, which is about 11 miles in. You'll enjoy some beautiful trail that winds throughout this heavily forested area, and then you'll start to climb towards the timberline. Enjoy the views from up there! West Jefferson splits off and takes you down along a creek for some beautiful hiking through the woods.

places.name: Ridgeline Open Space Trail
places.directions: Take exit 182 from I-25 and head west for 1.5 miles.Turn right on Coachline Rd and go 1 mile.Turn left on Foothills Dr and go .4 miles.Turn left on Clear Sky Way and go .25 miles.park at Bison Park on the left and access the trail from any of several trailheads within a block or two of here.

activities.name: Ridgeline Open Space Trail
activities.description: These soft-surface trails travel through valleys and ridgelines of the 370-acre open space property. Visitors can take in views of the Front Range to the west and the Town below as they traverse open grasslands and dense Gambel oak.

places.name: Coyote Valley
places.directions: Enter Rocky Mountain National Park from the main entrance at Estes Park. Keep heading east and it will turn into Trail Ridge Road. Travel all the way down Trail Ridge Road. At the end there will be several winding curves. You'll then be heading south on the west side of the park. About 5 miles later the Coyote Valley Trailhead will be on the right.If you're traveling from the west side of the park just head north on 34. The trailhead is on the left.

activities.name: Coyote Valley
activities.description: This is a half mile one-way trail and is completely wheelchair accessible. It's a very easy, kid-friendly hike with no change in elevation. The path starts out at the Colorado River and winds through a big meadow following the river with interpretive signs and benches along the way. Elk are often seem grazing out in the meadow.

places.name: North Lone Pine
places.directions: Take US 287 north from Ft. Collins or south from Laramie, WY to Red Feather Lakes Road (CR 74E).  Go west 24-25 miles to Deadman Road.  Take Deadman Road 4-5 miles to the trailhead on left (well marked).

activities.name: North Lone Pine
activities.description: The trail is relatively level at the beginning then ascends along North Lone Pine Creek. It passes a Forest Service experimental station plot, crosses the stream twice, and junctions with two old logging roads near some clear cuts before skirting east of North Bald Mountain and Middle Bald Mountain. Most of the trail is in mixed forest of lodgepole pine, spruce, fir, and aspen.  There are views of Red Feather Lakes and South Bald Mountain before the trail ends at Forest Road 517. Less than one half mile west on road 517, the south end of Killpecker Trail (#956) can be accessed. North Lone Pine trailhead accommodates approximately 5 vehicles.

places.name: North Catamount Reservoir
places.directions: There are a number of access points to North and South Catamount Reservoirs, but the easiest, in my opinion, is to head out of Woodland Park via Hwy 24 towards Divide.  Turn left onto Edlow Road, which is about 2.8 miles from WP, and take that all the way to the end (3.5 miles).  There is a parking lot with restrooms.

activities.name: North Catamount Reservoir
activities.description: North Catamount Reservoir has 10 miles of hiking trails that skirt the lake and wind through the nearby forests. Enjoy beautiful views of the reservoir and the surrounding area.  These trails are open to mountain bikers as well so be sure to share the trail!

places.name: Stillwater Pass
places.directions: From Grand Lake get on to Highway 34 heading South, as you near Lake Grandby there will be a sign on the right saying Stillwater Pass 1/4 of a mile away.  Take the next right and keep following this road.  The road will soon turn to dirt and there will be a parking lot on your right, drive past it.  Later on there will be a sign at an intersection with an arrow to the left says Idleglen Staging Area.  Take the left and park at Idleglen Staging area which is a little bit further and on the left.

activities.name: Stillwater Pass
activities.description: There are plenty of different trails at Stillwater Pass, ranging form 4x4 trails to beautiful singletrack. Find trails that will take you into pristine meadows with beautiful marshes and streams, or climb trails through the forest to reach the mountaintop for stunning views.  Head out to the Granby Ranger Station or Grand Lake Visitor Center, grab a map, and explore!

places.name: Spruce Canyon Trail
places.directions: Follow the main park road to Chapin Mesa and park at outside the Museum. Follow signs to the Spruce Tree House and the Spruce Canyon Trail.

activities.name: Spruce Canyon Trail
activities.description: A 2.4 mile loop along the edge of the picnic area and Spruce Tree House cliff dwelling. This hike takes you down into Spruce Canyon where you follow along a creek within the canyon walls. Then you climb back up the canyon onto a mesa where you can overlook where you've just been.

places.name: NEW SANTA FE REGIONAL TRAIL
places.directions: Colorado Springs CO
places.description: The 14 mile portion of the trail follows the abandoned Atkinson, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad right-of-way.  The gravel surfaced regional trail generally follows a straight and level course fo the first 6.5 miles beginning at Palmer Lake.  An easement agreement by the U.S. Air Force Academy provides a crucial 6.9 mile stretch of this trail.  Trail users must not go off the six-foot wide trail surface as it passes through the Academy.  Bicyclists must wear helmets.

activities.name: NEW SANTA FE REGIONAL TRAIL
activities.description: The 14 mile portion of the trail follows the abandoned Atkinson, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad right-of-way.  The gravel surfaced regional trail generally follows a straight and level course fo the first 6.5 miles beginning at Palmer Lake.  An easement agreement by the U.S. Air Force Academy provides a crucial 6.9 mile stretch of this trail.  Trail users must not go off the six-foot wide trail surface as it passes through the Academy.  Bicyclists must wear helmets.

places.name: Upper Upper Loop
places.directions: Ride west out of town on Teocalli Avenue to connect to the Rec Path. This gravel path crosses Brush Creek and then becomes paved, and heads up to the town of Mt. Crested Butte, meeting Gothic Road at the entrance to town. Cross Gothic Road on the crosswalk, and keep following the Rec Path until you see Hunter Hill Road on your right. (You could ride this bit on the road ... but why?) Turn right on Hunter Hill Road, and right again at the next intersection again on Hunter Hill. Go down, then up past The Overlook turnoff. The singletrack starts at the first hard left switchback, where thereâs a parking area and a trail sign.This is the beginning of Upper Loop. From here, you can connect to a bunch of trails, like Tony's Trail, Upper Upper Loop, Whetstone Vista, etc.

activities.name: Upper Upper Loop
activities.description: This trail is easily accessible from town and offers up some great views of the surrounding region and access to some deep aspen groves. Some sections of the trail are smooth, and some are very, very rocky.

places.name: Hall Ranch
places.directions: From Boulder, take US 36 / Foothills Hwy. north toward Lyons. Turn left on Hwy 66, then left on Hwy 7 / St. Vrain Rd. in Lyons. Trailhead is on the right.

activities.name: Hall Ranch
activities.description: Just west of the town of Lyons, you'll find the rolling grasslands and sandstone buttes of Hall Ranch. The over 3,000 acres of open space provides excellent viewing opportunities for wildflowers, animals, and scenic landscapes.  There are 5 trails ranging from moderate to difficult with the longest trail topping out at 4.7 miles. Dogs are not allowed due to wildlife concerns.

places.name: Boggy Draw Loop
places.directions: From Cortez, take Hwy 145 north 10 miles to Dolores.  In Dolores turn left on 11th St (turns into CR 31).  About 3 miles on 11th, and turn right on Road W.  East on W about 1 miles, cross the cattle grate and park in the lot in the left.

activities.name: Boggy Draw Loop
activities.description: Boggy Draw Loop offers 9 miles of beautiful singletrack through scenic forests and meadows. This day hike will take you under tree cover and then out into an open field where you can overlook the surrounding areas. The elevation doesn't change drastically, which makes it a nice, quiet day hike.  This is a multi-use trail so please practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Soapstone Natural Area
places.directions: Soapstone Prairie Natural Area (25 miles, one way) From Fort Collins take Hwy 1/ Terry Lake Road north, turn left onto County Rd 15 and travel north to Rawhide Flats Road. Turn right (north) onto Rawhide Flats Road and follow it to the Soapstone Prairie Natural Area entrance station.

activities.name: Soapstone Natural Area
activities.description: Soapstone is extraordinary with over 28 square miles of wide open vistas, nearly pristine grasslands, miles of trails and world-renowned cultural resources. The most popular recreation activities on natural areas are hiking or walking, wildlife watching and relaxing. A great benefit of being in a natural area is the stress relief one experiences, which is brought on by the warmth of the sun, fresh air, birds, grass blowing in the wind, and the sights, sounds and smells of nature.

places.name: Doctor Park
places.directions: From Gunnison, take highway 135 north to Almont, take a right on the Taylor River road (Forest Road 742), continue past the Spring Creek Road for about a half mile and turn left into the North Bank Campground.  Go thru the campground to the end of the road to find the trailhead.  From Crested Butte, go south on highway 135 and take Jacks Cabin Cutoff, which will put you on the Taylor River Road just west of Spring Creek Road.

activities.name: Doctor Park
activities.description: Doctor Park takes you through high alpine forests where the trail winds through beautiful aspens. At points the path leads out into open fields where you can take in stunning views of the surrounding mountains and valleys. Climb this trail up to the ridge and enjoy some great views. This is a multi-use trail so please keep an eye out for mountain bikers, and practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Trout Creek Trail
places.directions: To get to the trailhead from South Fork travel West on HWY 160 for approx 3 miles. The trailhead is on the right side of the highway in an open meadow with a livestock loading chute in the middle of it.

activities.name: Trout Creek Trail
activities.description: Trout Creek Trail is an incredibly scenic trail with wild raspberry bushes lining the trail and wild mint filling the air. The trail leads you along beautiful singletrack up to a meadow that's a perfect place to enjoy a little picnic.  This is a multi-use trail so please share the trail!

places.name: Black Cloud Trail
places.directions: Twin Lakes

activities.name: Black Cloud Trail
activities.description: 6 mile hiking trail located near Leadville, Colorado

places.name: Rabbit Ears Trail
places.directions: Take I-70 west to Exit 2, Rabbit Valley.  Turn left across the interstate and then turn left again on the frontage road.  Go east on the frontage road 4-5 miles and look for a sign for "Rabbit Ears" and a small parking area on the right.

activities.name: Rabbit Ears Trail
activities.description: Trail is a lollipop.  It climbs for the first two miles (go left at trail fork) to an overlook, then wraps around the top of a mesa for a mostly flat to downhill walk back to the intersection.  Beautiful views of the Colorado River, Bookcliffs, etc.

places.name: Apex Park
places.directions: From the I-25 and 6th Ave. intersection in Denver, go west on 6th. As you get close to the foothills, you will drive under I-70.After the underpass, take your first left at the stoplight.You will be turning onto Hwy. 40. Drive on 40 for about a mile.  Pull into the Heritage Square parking lot on your right, and park on the north side next to the trailhead.

activities.name: Apex Park
activities.description: Apex Trail is in the Jefferson County trail system, and the eastern access is in the City of Golden. The trail is 2.3 miles long gaining up to 1,500 feet in elevation. There are exposed steep trails at time with views of Denver and Golden.  Apex Park also features the Enchanted Forest Loop, at 5.6 miles round-trip, which features gentle slopes and scenic views of the forest. The Pick N' Sledge loop is also available, at 4.4 miles, but it is mainly used as a mountain bike trail. These trails are multi-use so please practice caution.

places.name: CDT CO05: South River Peak to Squaw Pass
places.directions: Closest easily-accessible trailhead is Wolf Creek Pass: 37.4828, -106.7999

activities.name: CDT CO05: South River Peak to Squaw Pass
activities.description: The CDT runs 23.5 miles between South River Peak and Squaw Pass. Along the way the trail passes Piedra Peak, Knife Edge, Cherokee Lake, and Chief Mountain.

places.name: Colorado National Monument
places.directions: For travelers going westbound through the Grand Valley: Take Highway I-70 to Grand Junction, and take Exit 31 (Horizon Drive). Follow signs through Grand Junction to the east entrance.For travelers going eastbound through the Grand Valley: Take Highway I-70 to Exit 19 (Fruita) and go south on Highway 340 to the west entrance, which is approximately three miles from Fruita. The visitor center and campground are four miles up from the west entrance.Source: National Park Service

activities.name: Colorado National Monument
activities.description: Colorado National Monument's trails offer many opportunities for hikers. Bird watchers and photographers discover the splendor that they traveled so far to find. Hikes range from only 0.25 mile to over 14 miles. Source: National Park Service

places.name: CDT CO10: Stony Pass Trailhead to Carson Saddle Trailhead
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO10: Stony Pass Trailhead to Carson Saddle Trailhead
activities.description: The CDT runs for 16 miles from Stony Pass Trailhead north to Carson Saddle Trailhead. Along the way it passes Canby Mountain, Half Peak, Tundra Top, Cataract Peak, Carson Peak, and Bent Peak.

places.name: Dedisse Trail
places.directions: From I-70 west of Denver, take Evergreen Parkway/HWY 74 to Upper Bear Creek Road [ just before the lake] Turn right follow Upper Bear Creek about 1/2 mile turn left and park at the lake house.

activities.name: Dedisse Trail
activities.description: Dedisse Trail is a fairly easy out-and-back trail that's perfect for a family with children or a leisurely day hike. Walk through deep forests, with beautiful boulders and rock formations, and enjoy the views of the lake along the hike.  This is a multi-use trail so please be aware of mountain bikers and practice trail etiquette.

places.name: CDT CO03: Elwood Pass to Wolf Creek Pass
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO03: Elwood Pass to Wolf Creek Pass
activities.description: Section 3 of the CDT in Colorado runs for 17.6 miles from Elwood Pass to Wolf Creek Pass. Along the way it passes Bonito Pass, Silver Mountain, Silver Pass, the Wolf Creek Ski Area, and Alberta Peak.

places.name: South Saint Vrain
places.directions: From Nederland, go north on 72/peak to peak highway.Roughly 3 miles north of Ward take a left on 96(Beaver Res. Rd on google maps).  Right after you get on 96 there will be the trailhead on the left, the large sign for the trail is about 20 feet or so off the road so its not VERY apparent, I drove clear past it the first time.  Just park along the road.Here's a link to google maps.http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&source=s_d&saddr=W+2nd+St%2FCO-72&daddr=Beaver+Res+Rd%2FCounty+Rd-96&geocode=FczHYQIdFAi2-Q%3BFcv1YwIdGmO2-Q&hl=en&mra=ls&sll=40.040232,-105.45639&sspn=0.313312,0.705872&ie=UTF8&t=p&z=11

activities.name: South Saint Vrain
activities.description: From County Road 96, the South Vrain Trail climbs west along South Saint Vrain Creek. In about two miles, the trail follows an old road, then turns off to the right (north) and climbs to avoid private property. At the top of this climb, the trail crosses an old road with signs to the Stapp Lakes. The Stapp Lakes are on private property with no public access. At 3.1 miles, South Saint Vrain Trail crosses the Sourdough Trail. The trail continues gently along a little ridge for another mile to an intersection with the Waldrop Trail. The trail drops down and crosses a creek before the Brainard Lake Cutoff Trail forks left (south). The South Saint Vrain Trail crosses a meadow to reach the Mitchell Lake Trailhead spur road north of Brainard Lake.

places.name: CDT CO01: New Mexico Border to Blue Lake AP
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO01: New Mexico Border to Blue Lake AP
activities.description: Section one of the Continental Divide Trail in Colorado runs 30.3 miles from the New Mexico border, past Cumbres Pass (and the trailhead there), past Three Lakes, Past Dripping Lakes, and it ends at a trailhead near Blue Lake. The Google Maps location given is for the point where the CDT crosses the New Mexico/Colorado Border. A better parking spot would be further north at Cumbres Pass: lat=37.01797644, lon=-106.450062146 Or you could park at the northern end of this section: lat=37.238152, lon=-106.628989

places.name: Turkey Flats
places.directions: Coming from Fruita or Grand Junction: Go through Colorado Natl Monument and take the road to Glade Park. Drive to intersection where you will find the glade park store on corner. Take road 16.50 south( you will pass a campground on right @ ~ 7 miles)   the road will fork at 8 miles stay right( sign for fruita resevoirs). Come to a picnic area on left side of road at 10 miles. Park in the lot.

activities.name: Turkey Flats
activities.description: Turkey Flats is a 10 mile loop trail near Fruita, CO. This trail will lead you through beautiful aspen meadows on smooth singletrack, and every once in a while you'll get stunning views of the surrounding valley and the mountains in the distance.  This is a multi-use trail, so please share the path.

places.name: Brockover Mesa
places.directions: CO

activities.name: Brockover Mesa
activities.description: Expansive network of trails up the mountains from Pagosa Springs in the San Juan National Forest.

places.name: Mount Bierstadt
places.directions: Take 285 from Denver to the town of Grant. Turn right onto Guanella Pass Road and drive about 13 miles up to the top of the pass. The trail begins there.

activities.name: Mount Bierstadt
activities.description: This may be one of the easiest and most accessible 14ers in Colorado, and as such it's a really popular route. That doesn't mean it's not worth the hike, though! The trail climbs up from the pass about 3.5 miles until it tops out on Mount Bierstadt at 14,060 feet after an elevation gain of 2,850 feet. The lower section of the trail is pretty flat as it approaches the main climb. It runs through some shrubby trees that are very short, since it is already over 11,000 feet. As soon as the trail starts climbing you rise above the tree line, and while it does climb up a peak, the trail isn't too steep or technical. Towards the top of the ridge right before you reach the summit, there are a few boulders that you have to scramble up but they aren't difficult at all. The views on this hike and from the top are absolutely incredible! Definitely bring your camera! Also, please note that this trail does enter the Mount Evans Wilderness. Please be aware of all of the special wilderness regulations.

places.name: Mount Margaret
places.directions: Take Highway 287 North from Fort Collins to to Livermore. Turn west on 74E for 22 miles to the trailhead. The trailhead is on the right side of the highway.

activities.name: Mount Margaret
activities.description: The trail crosses South Lone Pine Creek then meanders through meadows, sparse stands of lodgepole and ponderosa pine trees, and granite outcroppings. Five designated campsites, each with a bench, enclosed fire pit and grill, have been established within the first 2.5 miles for use on a first-come, first-served basis. The trail often follows old logging roads. It passes through an area known as Five Points which is the intersection of five roads/trails. At least one trail originates in Dowdy Lake Campground, and others are loops off the main trail.  Several more designated, dispersed campsites can be found along these routes. The trail continues past Five Points for nearly 2 miles to the base of Mount Margaret overlooking a deep canyon, North Lone Pine Creek and the Prairie Divide Road. Mount Margaret trailhead accommodates approximately 23 vehicles.

places.name: Waterdog Lakes
places.directions: Off of Hwy 50 near Monarch Park

activities.name: Waterdog Lakes
activities.description: The Water Dog Lakes trail is about 2 miles one-way or 3.7 miles round-trip. This trail climbs about a thousand vertical feet on the way up to the lake, but the pristine beauty of this high alpine lake is definitely a sight to behold!

places.name: Prospect Trail
places.directions: You can start the trial from the top of the free Gondola.  Ride the Gondola up from Mountain Village or downtown Telluride.

activities.name: Prospect Trail
activities.description: Prospect Trail starts at the top of the free gondola from Mountain Village. This hike follows a well-maintained trail that winds through the thick forests. Ever now and then it will cross with some ski trails, where you'll be able to get stunning views of the surrounding mountains and the town down below. Please share the trails with mountain bikers.

places.name: Commando Run
places.directions: Exit off I-70 at Vail and find a place to park.  From there bike to the closest mountain access point (they change frequently).

activities.name: Commando Run
activities.description: You'll be climbing up a lot of 4X4 trails on this hike. Go about 1.5 miles in until you see Chair 10, and then stay left. You'll keep climbing from here until you reach Benchmark at about 10 miles in. Turn right here and then after about a quarter mile, you'll see a spur trail off to your left, and you'll want to take that.  Climb to the top and take in the stunning views of the mountains and the valley below. All of that climbing is worth it!

places.name: Spruce Tree House Trail
places.directions: Travel to the far end of Mesa Verde National Park along HWY 10.  Park in the main lot.  Several trail begin from same parking lot, so look for signs

activities.name: Spruce Tree House Trail
activities.description: Short hike down across a canyon to one of the cliff dwelling houses this park is famous for.  This is one of the easier to access houses that does not require climbing.

places.name: Paint Mines Interpretive Park
places.directions: highway 24 to Calhan, south on Yoder and east on Paint Mine Rd.  There are several parking areas for the park.

activities.name: Paint Mines Interpretive Park
activities.description: Hidden in the eastern prairie is a unique geological feature referred to as the Paint Mines.  Consisting of colorful clay deposits there is evidence of early activity in this area making it of historic interest as well.  The "hoodoos" are well worth the stop.

places.name: Dry Fork Trail
places.directions: From Durango, take US 160 West about 3 miles and turn right onto Lightner Creek Road (County Road 207).  Go about a mile and turn right onto Dry Fork Road (County Road 208).  After about 2 miles, go right at the Y intersection, park at the trailhead on the left after about a mile.  Ride up the trail and take the left turn at the first intersection onto Dry Fork trail.  When you hit the Colorado Trail, take a right, then a right onto Hoffheins to complete the loop.  You'll climb about 1200 feet over the 4 or 5 miles to the top.

activities.name: Dry Fork Trail
activities.description: This 9 mile trail winds through the beautiful forests of Durango. Aspens shade this trail, and create a great atmosphere for a relaxing hike. All along the trail there are beautiful views of the surrounding area, which make this hike incredibly scenic.
