It does tend to get crowded, even on the weekdays, but don't let that stop you from enjoying the trail! This is a multi-use trail, so please practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Marshall Road Open Spaces
places.directions: Heading South from Boulder on HWY 93, take a left heading East on Marshall Road.  The trail parking lot will be on your right hand side.  You cannot miss it.  Heading from Denver, take US 36 heading northwest until you get to the Superior/Layfette exit.  On the off-ramp intersection take a left heading south.  You will pass back over the high way and take a right at the intersection heading toward Wild Oats and Super Target.  This Road will turn into Marshall Road.  You will stay on this road heading west for about 5 miles.  The Marshall Road turn off will be on your left after you pass the cattle range.  If you hit HWY 93 you have gone to far.  Turn around and look for the trailhead on your right.

activities.name: Marshall Road Open Spaces
activities.description: Marshall Road Open Spaces has a variety of trails totaling 7 miles just outside of Superior, Colorado. This area mostly has a desert feel and the trails run through wide open grassy plains providing beautiful views of the Flatirons.  Some of these trails are open to mountain bikers so please be aware and share the path.

places.name: Midland Bike Trail
places.directions: From Hwy 24 in Buena Vista, go east on Main St.  (This is at the stoplight)  Go about 1 mile to a park on the Arkansas River.  That is the trailhead.

activities.name: Midland Bike Trail
activities.description: This is one of the most popular mountain biking routes in Buena Vista. The ride starts with a fun stretch of singletrack that climbs up from the Arkansas River. At the top, you'll find spectacular views of Mount Princeton and the southern Arkansas Valley from the old Midland Railroad grade along CR 304. Once you turn east, the trail returns to singletrack that slices through narrow stone cuts and drops into diversions that wind down through draws once spanned by rail trestles. The trail is approximately 7.3 miles from trailhead-to-trailhead, but it's possible to shorten the ride by turning back sooner.  Hiking is allowed here, but remember that this trail is meant for mountain bikers. Please practice trail etiquette and share the path.

places.name: East-west Regional Trail
places.directions: Currently the main access and parking is in Highlands Ranch; trail will eventually extend to Lone Tree and Parker. Take C-470 south to S. University Blvd, right on Wildcat Reserve Pkwy, left on McArthur Ranch Rd. to Griggs Rd. Drive south 2 miles to trailhead on left. Or from Santa Fe take Daniels Park Rd. north 5 miles to Griggs Rd.; trailhead on right.

activities.name: East-west Regional Trail
activities.description: This is the first leg of the East/West Regional Trail that will connect Chatfield State Park with the Town of Parker. The trail winds through grasslands and oak bluffs including thousand of acres of the Open Space Conservation Area.

places.name: Pulpit Rock Park
places.directions: take I-25 to the Nevada Exit and head east.  Once ease of I-25 turn left on to the frontage road and head north.  Take road until it ends and you will see the pulpit rock parking lot.

activities.name: Pulpit Rock Park
activities.description: Pulpit Rock Park is a 6 mile hiking trail in Colorado Springs, Colorado.

places.name: Kessel Run
places.directions: Take 17.5 from town to N 3/10 road and hang a right. Turn left on 18 road and go until the pavement runs out, then stay on the dirt road for 4.3 miles and the trailhead is on the left. From the trailhead, ride on up the dirt road up to the Joe's Ridge/Prime Cut junction and kessel will be on the left.

activities.name: Kessel Run
activities.description: This hike starts out winding through some desert trees and descending down the mountain. It's a fairly quick hike that can be rocky at times, but it's a great place to get out and stretch your legs. Use it as an out-and-back trail or connect to the other network of trails at the end.  Please note that these trails are mainly used as mountain bike trails, and there is a high amount of bike traffic in the area.

places.name: Highline Lake State Park
places.directions: Drive west on I-70 west from Grand Junction to Loma Exit, then north onto Colorado Highway 139 for six miles to Q Road. Go west on Q road for 1.2 miles, then turn north onto 11.8 Road for one mile to the East park entrance.
places.description: An oasis in the desert, Highline Lake is the recreation epicenter for the Grand Valley with two lakes, lush grass, trails and trees.

activities.name: Highline Lake State Park
activities.description: Several trails circle Mack Mesa Lake and Highline Lake. The park is close to the well-known Kokopelli trail complex and the newer, North Fruita Desert Trails bike trail complex. There are a total of 7 trails, mostly loop trails, ranging from easy to difficult with the longest trail topping out at 6.42 miles. Remember to share the trail!

places.name: Florissant Fossil Beds National Monument
places.directions: DIRECTIONS: Visitors traveling north/south on I-25: Exit at US 24 West, travel 35 miles to town of Florissant, then follow signs two miles south to the visitor center on Teller County 1. Visitors traveling east/west on US 24: Exit to the town of Florissant, then follow signs two miles south on Teller County 1 to the visitor center. Visitors traveling from the town of Cripple Creek: Follow Teller County Road 1 north for 16 miles. TRANSPORTATION: To Park: access by US Highway 24 and Teller County Road 1.Source: National Park Service

activities.name: Florissant Fossil Beds National Monument
activities.description: There are over 14 miles of hiking trails in the Monument. Most of the trails wind through pine covered hills with patches of Aspen and Douglas Fir. Some of the trails pass wet meadows or through riparian areas. Source: National Park Service

places.name: Cub Lake
places.directions: Enter Rocky Mountain National Park from the main entrance at Estes Park. Go past the Beaver Meadows Visitor Center and turn left onto Bear Lake Road. Turn into the Moraine Park Campground. Then take Fern Lake Road to the left. This road takes you to the Cub Lake Trailhead, below the campground.

activities.name: Cub Lake
activities.description: This trail is 2.3 miles one way to Cub Lake. With an elevation gain of only 540 ft it's a great introductory hike to the park. You'll first cross a bridge over a river, then meander along on a dirt path with lots of pines and aspens on either side. There are beautiful streams and ponds along the way and cascading cliffs overhead. Once you get to Cub Lake you can then either turn around and go back or continue on to Fern Lake.

places.name: Spring Creek Trail
places.directions: Lincoln Ave (US 40), East on 5th St 2 blocks.  Angle onto Maple St. continue to Amethyst.  Park on the side of the gravel/dirt road.

activities.name: Spring Creek
activities.description: The Spring Creek Trail is a 5.2 mile, multi-use trail that is popular for hiking and biking with residents and visitors of Steamboat. The trail becomes a classic single track on City of Steamboat Springs property for the next 1.5 miles, climbing gently along the creek. The last 1.4 miles of the trail continues to climb in the Routt National Forest to the end of the trail at Dry Lake Campground, off of RCR # 38, Buffalo Pass Road. Please share the trail.

places.name: Mary's Loop / Horsethief Bench
places.directions: Take I-70 to exit #15. The Kokopelli trailhead parking lot is just off the exit on Frontage road. From the parking lot, ride up the hill on the gravel road into the valley. Ride down the gravel road, the trail will be climbing jeep road on the right just before the rustlers loop parking area.

activities.name: Mary's Loop/Horsethief Bench
activities.description: This trail has plenty to keep you interested. From the beautiful overlooks where you can view the Colorado River, to the rock scrambles, to the wide open valley. This canyon hike will leave you satisfied. Watch out for mountain bike traffic!

places.name: Red Rocks/ Dakota Ridge
places.directions: Take I-70 west out of Denver. Go past the 470 exit, and take the very next exit for Morrison. At the end of the exit, take a left (south) onto Colorado Hwy 26 at the light. Go under the I-70 overpass, and the park will be on your right 100 yards later. Trailhead is on SE side of the lot.

activities.name: Dakota Ridge
activities.description: Dakota Ridge is an extremely rocky trail high on the Hogback between Denver and the front range. This is a very entertaining trail with rocks and staircases all over the place and some serious exposure on the tops of cliffs. Expect incredible views of Denver and the front range.

places.name: Sweitzer Lake State Park
places.directions: Sweitzer is located one mile south of Delta on U.S. 50. Follow the signs turning east on E. Road.
places.description: It started out as a community dream.  This lake based retreat for the Western Slope provides day-use nature, picnic and water recreation.

activities.name: Sweitzer Lake State Park
activities.description: 1 1/2 miles around the lake on dirt and gravel roads.

places.name: Glen Eyrie
places.directions: Go west to the end of Garden of the Gods Road and turn south onto N 30th street, 3820 N. 30th St. On the right before you get to Garden of the Gods.

activities.name: Glen Eyrie
activities.description: As of right now, because of the Waldo Canyon Fire, they are not allowing any public access to hiking trails.  The trails are located at the Glen Eyrie Castle.  You must get a hiking permit during the hours they are open to the public (see the official website: http://www.navigators.org/us/ministries/gleneyrie/).  The trails go through some canyons and there's a nice waterfall and pond.

places.name: West Magnolia
places.directions: From Nederland, take 119 South for about 1 mile.  On the West side, across from Magnolia (County Hwy 132) is the trailhead.

activities.name: West Magnolia
activities.description: West Magnolia Trailhead provides access to eight miles of singletrack trails for hiking, biking and horseback riding west of the Peak-to-Peak Highway south of Nederland. An additional eight miles of Forest Roads that connect to Rollins Pass Road west of Rollinsville are open to motorized and non-motorized activities.  The network of interconnected trails offers many different loop opportunities with a range of difficulty levels. It is possible to connect this system of trails with the Front Range Trailhead via a short segment of Magnolia Road east of Colorado Highways 72/119.

places.name: Bergen Peak
places.directions: Drive west on 1-70 to the evergreen parkway exit colorado 74 and travel through bergen park to elk meadow park. Pass lewis ridge park  and turn right on stage coach blvd. follow the signs to the parking lot

activities.name: Bergen Peak
activities.description: Bergen Peak trail starts off fairly flat winding its way through a beautiful meadow. Following that the climb starts, there are a few steep sections, but most of the ascent consists of switchbacks. The official top of the trail doesn't offer much in the way of views because of it's surrounded by trees, however there is a rocky outcropping nearby that has amazing views for hikers to enjoy.

places.name: Mount Sanitas
places.directions: Take Mapleton Ave. west until it turns into Sunshine Canyon Dr. Look for parking on either side of the road. There's also a small parking lot on the left side of the road just past the marked trailhead on the right.

activities.name: Mount Sanitas
activities.description: Classic Boulder hike with incredible views and within walking distance of downtown Boulder. The Sanitas Trail climbs a tall ridge with sweeping views to the east and west. Also be sure to hit the Sanitas Valley Trail, a wide, gradual path just east of Mt. Sanitas.

places.name: Mount Galbraith Park
places.directions: From State Highway 93, take Golden Gate Canyon Road west approximately 1.5 miles to the parking area and trailhead.

activities.name: Mount Galbraith Park
activities.description: Come for the challenging terrain, stay for the views. Mount Galbraith Park is a hiker-only destination, boasting nearly five miles of steep, rocky trails that reward the hardy with commanding views of Golden, the plains and the Continental Divide.  The Mt. Galbraith Loop circles 1.6 miles around the top of the 7,260-foot peak. In addition to the vast and varying landscape, keep your eyes peeled for the elk, bighorn sheep, red-tailed hawks and songbirds that frequent the area.   Mount Galbraith is flanked by Clear Creek Canyon and Golden Gate Canyon, which were vital passageways into the Central Rockies for Native Americans and settlers. Miners climbed the mountain to access the western territories during the California gold rush of 1849, as travel was easier along the ridgelines than through dense drainages.

places.name: Cr-81 To Rendezvous
places.directions: From the top of CR-81 (FSR 128) Down Twisted Ankle to Whoops trail, Whoops to Idlewild, And into the Winterwoods Loop, Which turns into Serendipity. Serendipity to Crosstrails, Crosstrails to Homestead which Spits you out in Rondezvous, which if you follow the road down, will land you right on the main road halfway between Winter Park and Fraser closer to the Winter Park side.

activities.name: Cr-81 To Rendezvous
activities.description: Cr-81 To Rendezvous is a 3 mile hiking trail in Winter Park, Colorado.

places.name: Farris Creek
places.directions: from Crested Butte follow the New Deli trail out to South Crested Butte, only a couple of miles; then follow the county road (Brush Creek Road) out past the trailhead to Cold Spring Ranch, about 2 miles; there is a right turn up a fairly steep hill, approx 1/2 mile beyond Cold Spring Ranch; on completing the trail you end up on this county road, follow it back to South CB and then CB itself

activities.name: Farris Creek
activities.description: The Farris Creek trail is 6.1 miles long. It begins at Forest Road 740 and ends at Forest Road 736. The trail is open for the following uses: Hiking, Mountain Biking, Horseback Riding, and Motorcycle Trail Riding. This out-and-back trail crosses open plains, revealing the tall mountains rising around you, and it also winds through thick, secluded forests. It's a perfect place to get outside, but remember to share the trail!

places.name: Elkhead State Park
places.directions: From Craig, go seven miles east on Highway #40 turn left onto County Road #29.  Signs will direct you to Elkhead Reservoir, approximately 3 miles.
places.description: Elkhead State Park in the beautiful Yampa Valley of Northwest Colorado is an oasis in the high desert.

activities.name: Elkhead State Park
activities.description: Elkhead State Park in the beautiful Yampa Valley of Northwest Colorado is an oasis in the high desert. This 900 acre reservoir provides endless recreational opportunities. They include, but are not limited to, boating, swimming, jet skiing, skiing, picnicking, wildlife watching, hiking, camping, meeting friends and neighbors, bird watching, biking, horseback riding hunting and fishing and many photo opportunities. Hike along one of a variety of trails that follow the lakeshore. Although many are short hikes, they can be very rewarding to the conscious viewer.

places.name: Lovell Gulch
places.directions: From Colorado Springs, take I-25 and Hwy 24 West towards Woodland Park.  Once in Woodland Park, turn right at the McDonalds onto Baldwin Rd.  Head straight through several stop signs for about 2 miles.  There will be a sign to turn left into the parking lot for the Lovell Gulch Trailhead, which is adjacent to an animal shelter.

activities.name: Lovell Gulch
activities.description: Lovell Gulch is an nice 5 mile loop trail that has relatively easy climbs but stunningly beautiful views. Hike through dense forests and skirt large granite boulders along the trail. Dive down into some small valleys and then hike along a ridge that showcases Pikes Peak and the Sawatch Range.

places.name: Haymeadow Trail
places.directions: From I-70, exit 147, go south into Eagle.  Go right at the roundabout onto Grand Ave then take the 2nd left onto Capitol St.  Follow Capitol through the old part of Eagle.  After emerging from the old part of Eagle, you will reach a 3-way stop--go left here onto Brush Creek Rd.  Follow Brush Creek Road through some residential development and it will loop around and dead end at the Eagle Pool and Ice Rink.  Park here--the trail leads due south from here.  Be sure to ride the trail counterclockwise.

activities.name: Haymeadow Trail
activities.description: 6 mile hiking trail located near Eagle, Colorado

places.name: Rifle Falls State Park
places.directions: Take I-70 to the Rifle exit (90), then go north on CO Highway 13 for four miles. This takes you through the town of Rifle on Railroad Ave. Turn right onto Highway 325 and drive 9.8 miles.
places.description: Rifle Falls State Park's lush vegetation and waterfalls have attracted photographers and movie crews from around the country who come to capture the area's unique scenery.

activities.name: Rifle Falls State Park
activities.description: Three unique hiking trails meander along the creek and through luxuriant riparian area throughout the park. They provide access to the caves, the top of the falls, and the creek upstream and downstream from the park. The Bobcat Trail follows Rifle Creek to the Colorado Division of Wildlife's Fish Hatchery. See the Trails section for complete trail descriptions. Please use caution as parts of the trails are steep and can become slippery when wet. Come prepared with sturdy hiking boots and plenty of water.

places.name: Independence Monument
places.directions: The lower entrance to Independence Monument can be difficult to locate.  Take Hwy 340 west.  You'll drive through the Redlands area, past Independence Valley subdivision and into a more rural area.  Just past an intersection with Deer Valley you'll approach a curve to the right with a large house sitting on the left.  What looks like a driveway right here on the left is actually the turn off to your trailhead.

activities.name: Independence Monument
activities.description: From the trailhead you'll hike behind houses for a bit before the trail turns and begins winding its way into the Monument.  The trail is well-maintained and not very steep.  It's about 2.5 miles to the Independence Monument monolith.  If you hike further you can see other formations like the Coke Ovens and Kissing Couple.  If you're quiet you might also see Bighorn Sheep!

places.name: CDT CO39: Troublesome Pass to FR104
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO39: Troublesome Pass to FR104
activities.description: The CDT runs 11.4 miles from Troublesome Pass to FR104. Along the way, the trail passes Poison Ridge, Sheep Mountain, and Hyannis Peak.

places.name: Finch Lake
places.directions: Located between the towns of Meeker and Allenspark on Colorado route 7 (Peak to Peak Scenic Highway). Watch for signs.

activities.name: Finch Lake
activities.description: Located in the Wild Basin Area of Rocky Mountain National Park, this trail leads 4.6 miles out to the secluded and pristine Finch Lake. You'll hike through thick forests and wide open fields to get to your destination, where you'll be able to look out over across the lake to the Continental Divide.  There are backcountry camping spots available around Finch Lake, just in case you wanted to get away for a little while longer.

places.name: Ringtail-swallowtail
places.directions: Hikers and horse riders may access from Sharptail Ridge Trailhead. From Hwy 85 (Santa Fe) turn west on Titan Parkway and drive 2 miles to Roxborough Road; turn left and drive south for 3.7 miles on gravel road; Sharptail trailhead on the left. NOTE: Hikers and horse riders accessing from Sharptail Trailhead must travel approximately 8 miles before reaching the eastern end of Ringtail Trail.Multiple users, including mountain bikes and pets on a leash, can access from the Indian Creek Trailhead of Pike National Forest; however access from Indian Creek Trail does require a daily parking fee of $4 (7/04 price). Note: From the Indian Creek Trailhead to the western end of Ringtail Trail is a distance of approximately 5.7 miles.

activities.name: Ringtail-swallowtail
activities.description: Ringtail-swallowtail climbs up into the beautiful and scenic Pike Hill Open Space in the Pike National Forest. The trail winds through forests and when it reaches the Open Space you get stunning views of the surrounding area! Please share the trail with mountain bikers.

places.name: Cedar Mountain
places.directions: Cedar Mountain is accessed by taking U.S. Highway 40 west from Craig 1 mile, turn right on (County Road 7), go north for 5 miles then turn right on Cedar Mountain Access (BLM Route # 2190). http://www.blm.gov/co/st/en/fo/lsfo/programs/recreation/cedar_mtn.html

activities.name: Cedar Mountain
activities.description: 3 mile hiking trail located near Craig, Colorado

places.name: CDT CO26: Tennessee Pass to Copper Mountain
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO26: Tennessee Pass to Copper Mountain
activities.description: Section 26 of the CDT in Colorado runs 24.6 miles from the trailhead at Tennessee Pass / US Hwy 24 to Copper Mountain / Hwy 91. Along the way, the trail passes US Hwy 24, Sheep Mountain, North Sheep Mountain, Elk Mountain, Jacque Peak, and Copper Mountain Ski Resort.

places.name: Holy Cross
places.directions: See the Pet-a-Kes trail for directions to the trailhead.

activities.name: Holy Cross
activities.description: Located in the Redlands area of Grand Junction, this trail is a fun hike full of climbing around boulders and enormous trees. Enjoy the desert landscape that the trail winds through, but know that this trail was built for mountain bikers.  Remember to share the trail and practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Wildcat Mountain/Monarch
places.directions: Take Wildcat Reserve and make a right onto McAurther Ranch Parkway, than make another right on To Monarch and than travel for a little over a mile, after a turn in the road there is a very small driveway into a parking lot on the left side enter the lot slowly. You can only ride this trail if you have a Highlands ranch Rec card.

activities.name: Monarch Backcountry
activities.description: This is a private trail for the residents of Highlands Ranch.  The trail takes you past low-lying desert shrubs, through beautiful prairie fields, alongside small ponds, and it provides awesome views the whole way. This trail is open to mountain bikers as well so be sure to share the trail!

places.name: Trading Post
places.directions: 15 miles west of Denver. Coming from Downtown, take I-70 west to exit 259, turn left at the bottom of the Morrison exit ramp, cruise on downhill 1.5 miles to the Red Rocks Park entrance. Coming from south Denver, take C-470 to the Morrison exit, turn west and follow the signs to the Park entrances.

activities.name: Trading Post
activities.description: The Trading Post Trail goes through spectacular rock formations, valleys and a natural meadow. The trail is 6,280 feet above sea level. The majority of the trail is less than 30 inches wide.

places.name: Sutton Mine Trail
places.directions: Departing Ouray on Highway 550 south, turn right after the first switchback onto the Camp Bird Road (CR 361). The trailhead will be found on the left, about half way up Jim Brown Hill (the more or less straight part of the road where you can look down on the town of Ouray, to the right). There is limited parking at the trailhead. If full, park near the powder house below the bridge over the Uncompahgre.

activities.name: Sutton Mine Trail
activities.description: The trail starts off with a half mile of very steep switchbacks, but then flattens.  At 2 miles you'll reach the Bear Creek Overlook and at 2.5 the Neosho Mine.  Beautiful views!  Take a trekking pole.

places.name: CDT CO06: Squaw Pass to Weminuche Pass
places.directions: Closest easily-accessible trailhead is Wolf Creek Pass: 37.4828, -106.7999

activities.name: CDT CO06: Squaw Pass to Weminuche Pass
activities.description: The CDT runs for 12.9 miles between Squaw Pass and Weminuche Pass. Along the way the route runs past the Squaw Lake Trail and Snowslide Trail.

places.name: Tom Blake Trail
places.directions: From I-70 exit #116 and take HWY 82 towards Aspen. At Brushcreek Rd. turn R and proceed uphill until you reach Base Village at Snowmass, parking is abundant. From here, are several options to access the mountain to Tom Blake Trail. Grab a free trail map at any of the bike shops in the area.

activities.name: Tom Blake Trail
activities.description: Tom Blake Trail is a 6 mile trail that leads you through thick forests where you'll see beautiful aspen trees. This trail is perfect for a quiet stroll through the woods! This trail is multi-use, so please share the trail!

places.name: CDT CO25: Timberline Lake to Tennessee Pass
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO25: Timberline Lake to Tennessee Pass
activities.description: Section 25 of the CDT in Colorado runs just over 13 miles from Timberline Lake to Tennessee Pass on US Hwy 24. Along the way, the trail passes Galena Mountain, West Tennessee Creek, Homestake Peak, and Missouri Hill.

places.name: Arkansas Hills
places.directions: there are three ways to get in to the town of Salida, from Colroado 291 from Buena vista. hwy 50 from Poncha Springs and hwy 50 from canyon city. from Salida look for F street and go over the F street Bridge. the road ends and leads you in to a parking area. From there you must bike over railroad tracks. You can take the Front Side Trail or Bike up to CR 177.

activities.name: Arkansas Hills
activities.description: This is the closest trail system to downtown Salida. The trail system is a combination of 11 hiking and biking trails that range from 0.4 miles to 3.2 miles in length. There are several access points and all trails are well-maintained and well-marked.  These trails are multi-use trails so please practice caution.

places.name: Palisade Rim
places.directions: Park by the Colorado River along US 6 near the mouth of DeBeque Canyon.

activities.name: Palisade Rim
activities.description: Palisade Rim is a beautiful out-and-back trail that you can connect with other trails in the network to make a loop. The trail follows along the rim and the edge of the cliffs, giving you an amazing view of the surrounding area. This trail is shared by mountain bikers so please share the path.

places.name: Eleven Mile SP
places.directions: From Colorado Springs take Hwy 24 west for 38 miles through Lake George. West of Lake George, turn left (south) on County Rd 90 and follow it for four miles. From that point, continue south on County Rd 92 for six miles to the park.
places.description:
Eleven Mile SP is esteemed for its outstanding fishing. Eleven Mile is also a popular site for sailing, windsurfing, boating, hiking and camping. 

The park offers nine campgrounds, five miles of hiking/biking and a convenient equipment rental center for boaters and ice-fishers. It's a great location for a variety of activities and scenic views.

activities.name: Eleven Mile SP
activities.description: Eleven Mile SP is esteemed for its outstanding fishing. Eleven Mile is also a popular site for sailing, windsurfing, boating, hiking and camping.   The park offers several hiking trails with various levels of difficulty. Some of which are the  self-guided Nature Trail and an Orienteering trail. The trails offer beautiful meadow views, wildlife sightings and a backcountry peninsula view.

places.name: Thunder Pass
places.directions: From Fort Collins, CO drive up Hwy 14, the Poudre Canyon, until you get to Cameron Pass about 60 mi from town. Park at the summit parking lot and ride across the road to the Michigan Ditch TH. There is a fee station just ahead $3.00/person

activities.name: Thunder Pass
activities.description: Thunder Pass is a 12 mile hiking trail in Fort Collins, Colorado.

places.name: Brown's Lake Trail
places.directions: right off of crown point road

activities.name: Brown's Lake Trail
activities.description: 8 mile out and back. Located near Bellvue, CO. This trail is great for backpacking, camping and fishing!

places.name: Pet - A - Kes
places.directions: This trail starts along with all the other Tabeguache/Lunch Loops trails.  From Grand Junction, head west on Broadway aka Hwy 340.  Turn left on Monument road and follow it about a mile to the parking area on the left.

activities.name: Pet - A - Kes
activities.description: Pet-A -Kes is a 1 mile climb within the lunch loops trail network. Traverse rocky climbs to get to the top of this trail, and then take in the beautiful desert scenery it provides. You're sure to love this trail, and plenty of other people do too, so make sure you look out for other hikers and bikers and you share the trail!

places.name: Elk Park Trail
places.directions: Go to the Pikes Peak Toll road and park right outside the gate.  Get you 10$ per person ready and flag a truck to carry you and your bikes up the road.  Go .5 miles past Glen Cove and pull off the left to a parking area.  It\'s the only Trailhead.

activities.name: Elk Park Trail
activities.description: Elk Park Trail is an 11 mile out-and-back trail close to the Barr Trail on the famous Pikes Peak. Cross streams, scale mountains, and wind through forests along this scenic trail. It offers great views and gets you away from some of the crowds on the Barr Trail. This is a multi-use trail so please practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site
places.directions: The park is accessed via U.S. Highway 50 and Highway 194. From La Junta, Colorado on U.S. Highway 50, take Highway 109 north 1 mile to Highway 194, then east on Highway 194 six miles to the fort. From Las Animas, Colorado, on U.S. Highway 50, take Highway 194 west 13 miles. Set your GPS to 35110 State Highway 194 E., La Junta, CO.Source: National Park Service

activities.name: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site
activities.description: Visitors can hike a mile and a half trail that winds its way through the cottonwood trees alongside the Arkansas River. The marsh is home to several species of birds. Interpretive exhibit signs tell the story of the river ecosystem, Santa Fe Trail and Bent's Fort.  Source: National Park Service

places.name: Bear Creek Canyon Loop
places.directions: From I-25, take US 24 West to 21st St. Turn left onto 21st street, then right onto Lower Gold Camp Road. At the four way stop, turn left onto Bear Creek Road. Park on the side of the road at the end of Bear Creek Road or the parking lot at the caretaker's home at the end of High Drive.

activities.name: Bear Creek Canyon Loop
activities.description: This loop trail is difficult with a 2,200 elevation climb in the first 4 miles. Be ready for a great workout, but also enjoy this beautifully forested trail that has awesome overlooks where you can view the surrounding mountains. The downhill also features some creek crossings as well.  This is a multi-use trail so please practice caution as there is some mountain bike traffic here.

places.name: Mount Princeton Trail
places.directions: Princeton

activities.name: Mount Princeton Trail
activities.description: 3 mile hiking trail located near Salida, Colorado

places.name: Devils Backbone
places.directions: Starting from Taft and Eisenhower (highway 43) head west on highway 34. The has 2 lanes in each direction, the road will go down to one lane in each direction. The trail head is just a few minutes from this point. You will see a coffee shop (The Black Cup) on the right, after this bend you will see an old water tower on the right with a road before it. Turn right on this dirt road and you will see the a large Devils Backbone trailhead sign.

activities.name: Devils Backbone
activities.description: This trail goes on for at least 8 miles, and eventually connects up with several other trails in the area, but you only have to hike a mile or two to reach the Devil's Backbone. The Backbone is a line of rocks sticking out of the ground that looks like a bony spine. You've got to see this in person!

places.name: Colorado Trail / Waterton To South Platte
places.directions: Begin at the Waterton Canyon parking lot.  This lot is about 4 miles south of C-470 on Wadsworth Blvd.  It is easy to spot because the trail and parking lot is usually quite busy.

activities.name: Colorado Trail / Waterton To South Platte
activities.description: The first 6 miles of this section tends to get a little bit crowded. It's very popular for day hikes, so you'll find plenty of families and children climbing the trail. Head up to "sitting bench" and you'll break through the crowds a little. Continue to hike through beautiful forests and along rocky outcroppings, and enjoy the views!

places.name: The Boneyard
places.directions: From I-70 Eagle exit 147, follow first roundabout to right and make 1st left on Capitol St.  2 blocks then left on 3rd, go 1/2 mile and turn left on Mill Rd. (parking lot is on the left.

activities.name: The Boneyard
activities.description: The Boneyard is a 7 mile hiking trail in Eagle, Colorado.

places.name: Falcon Trail
places.directions: I-25 to Northgate of Air Force Academy Non-Military Entrance - Exit 156B. Once you go through security, take your first left onto Stadium Blvd, then a right onto Academy Dr. -- Parking lot at the top of the hill on the right side of the road (near the stadium).

activities.name: Falcon Trail
activities.description: This beautiful trail tours the grounds of the US Air Force Academy. The trail traverses wide open prairies and secluded low mountain woods. It's a great place to get some sights in while enjoying nature.  This is a multi-use trail so please be respectful, also expect a possible car search at the gate.

places.name: Hidden Mesa
places.directions: From Castle Rock take Highway 86 east toward Franktown.  Turn left at Parker road and continue on for approximately 1 mile.  Hidden Mesa Open Space will be on your left.

activities.name: Hidden Mesa
activities.description: Hike this 1224-acre open space buffer between Castle Rock and Franktown.  Embark on this soft-surface trail from the trailhead at the old homestead at Parker Road. Follow the farm lane as it crosses over Cherry Creek and then winds up to the top of the mesa where it loops around viewpoints, rock outcroppings, grass and shrublands, as well as pines and junipers.

places.name: CDT CO07: Weminuche Pass to Twin Lakes
places.directions: Closest easily-accessible trailhead is the Beartown Trailhead: lat=37.712333, lon=-107.518005

activities.name: CDT CO07: Weminuche Pass to Twin Lakes
activities.description: The CDT runs for 10.5 miles from Weminuche Pass north to Twin Lakes. Along the way the trail passes Lavaca Creek, Ute Lake, Rio Grand Pyramid, and Window Peak.

places.name: Heiser To Barr Trail
places.directions: Take Hwy 24. to Cascade. Turn Left at "Pikes Peak" light.  Take the first second left after you turn left.  If you miss the 2nd left, take the third.  Go up the road less than 1/4 mile to the park.  Jump on your bike and head on the small road going north/east.  Follow this road 1/8 mile to the trail head.  There are Private Property signs, but they apply to the driveways, not the road your on

activities.name: Heiser To Barr
activities.description: Heiser To Barr Trail is a difficult uphill climb to the pristine Manitou Reservoir. Once you reach the reservoir you start to head back down and the trail meets back up with the Barr Trail.  This is a hard 14 miles so make sure you're prepared and have plenty of water!

places.name: Roxborough State Park
places.directions: Take Wadsworth south past Chatfield State Park. Turn left on Waterton Road (just before the entrance to Lockheed Martin.) Continue on Waterton Road-crossing the South Platte River, until it ends at North Rampart Range Road (1.6 miles) Turn right (south) on North Rampart Range Road. Continue south past Roxborough Village and the Foothills Water Treatment Plant. (2.3 miles) At the intersection of North Rampart Range Road and Roxborough Park Road (just before the entrance to Arrowhead golf course), turn left onto Roxborough Park Road. Take the next right on East Roxborough Drive(about 50 yards away) to enter the park.
places.description: More than a million Denver-area residents have one of nature's jewels in their backyard: Roxborough State Park, a short drive southwest of Denver.

activities.name: Roxborough State Park
activities.description: Roxborough State Park offers a variety of trails for all abilities, from the half-mile Fountain Overlook trail that affords a spectacular view of rock formations, to the challenging 6.4-mile trek to 7,160-foot Carpenter Peak.

places.name: Picket Wire Canyon
places.directions: From La Junta go south on H109 and then turn on to CR802 into the Comanche Grass Lands. South on CR25 and follow the signs toward Withers Canyon trail head. After this it is recommended for a high clearance vehicle, but this was not needed on our trip.

activities.name: Picket Wire Canyon
activities.description: Long and mostly flat hike leading towards a historic mission, 1/4 mile stretch of dinosaur tracks, and a historic ranch.

places.name: A-10
places.directions: From I-70 Exit 163 take Edwards Access Rd. south to Hwy 6.  Turn left and go @ 1 mile to Miller Ranch Rd. (light) making a left, park @ one of the two schools.  Ride back across the Blue-light bridge and go left at the traffic light, continue riding to Arrowhead (on right) and climb up the road to the base of the chairlift and start of the trail.

activities.name: A-10
activities.description: Enjoy the views of Gold Dust Peak and the surrounding mountains while climbing up Arrowhead Mountain on this beautiful 8 mile loop trail. Hike through high meadows, oakbrush, and aspens, and enjoy a few creek crossings as well.  This trail is has a high amount of mountain bike traffic so please use caution.

places.name: Pollock Bench / Canyon
places.directions: From I-70 exit in Fruita, CO, turn left and cross the Colorado River.  Turn right onto King's View court.  Follow the road past Devil's Canyon and the Fruita Paleo trailhead to Pollock Canyon on the left.  There is a sign that says "dead end in 3/4 mile" right at the parking area.  The Pollock Bench trail, which overlooks Pollock Canyon heads up and to the right just past the map/register area.

activities.name: Pollock Bench / Canyon
activities.description: After a mostly uphill start, the trail flattens out and loops around the rim of Pollock Canyon with views into this to the south and Flume Canyon to the west.  Follow the signs for P1 clockwise or counterclockwise to complete the lollipop.

places.name: Deer Creek
places.directions: To ride it from Brush Creek, start from town and ride south on the bike path that parallels highway 135. Turn left on Brush Creek Road (County Road 738) and pass the entrance to the Skyland. Keep riding out Brush Creek Road for about five miles. At this point, youll cross Brush Creek on a good bridge and start climbing on the road. Youre passing through private ranchland here, so keep to the road. The road continues to climb and becomes rougher. At the "Y", stay left and begin climbing more steeply on West Brush Creek Road. The right takes you up East Brush Creek and Pearl Pass. The climb gets a little tougher at this point, then levels out before coming to another split in the road. Take another left onto Deer Creek Road. Right takes you further up West Brush Creek toward the Teocalli Ridge Trail (another classic ride).There are wooden signs at these intersections directing you. Deer Creek continues to climb up a rough double track. Go through a gate at the top of this climb and continue about 1/4 of a mile to another split in the road. Go left again and ride steeply down down through some aspens. Follow the doubletrack through a boggy area to its end, where the Deer Creek singletrack begins. The trail is very distinct and buffed along here.After two creek crossings, the trail starts to climb steadily and steeply. See how long you can stay on your bike. Ive seen a few very strong local riders ride all the way to the top of this one. It is a major push. At the top, whether youre walking or still riding, youll love the view of the upper East river valley and the back of Crested Butte Mountain. This is a great place to recover and have bite to eat. If youre lucky, youll see elk grazing in the aspen groves uphill from you.From here, the trail weaves and bobs its way along the flanks of Whiterock Mountain. There is everything you could want in a singletrack for the next seven miles. The trail is usually in great shape early in the summer. Later on, cows can hammer the trail if it rains a lot. There are a couple tricky places where the cows regularly make side trails. The first is right after you cross the wide and rocky Perry Creek at 13 and 1/2 miles. The main trail climbs up out of the creek and through the aspens a very short distance and turns sharply right to climb through a meadow. Dont be tempted to stay low and straight ahead on the well worn cow path!Again, at mile 15, after you start a steady and switchbacking descent through a meadow and then into the aspens, the trail makes a sharp turn back to the left and climbs quickly for 100 feet or so to avoid a boggy area. (Several cowpaths go straight down.) Next, follow the trail down the creek and to the right, crossing a couple small creeks and heading out into the open meadows, Gothic Mountain in view straight ahead. Follow this gradually rolling section through the meadows to the final descent. At one point (mile 17.3) the trail veers hard left at some private property. There is a sign here, dont miss it! Continue to the left through the meadows, then curve right and down to a doubletrack. Take a right on this rough road and ride out to Gothic Road (the main gravel road). Turn left on Gothic Road, cross the East River and begin riding back toward town. After a gradual, three mile climb, top out on the road climb above Mount Crested Butte. Still feeling strong? You can ride the Snodgrass Trail (just to the right) on the way back. Or you can continue on the fast road back to town.

activities.name: Deer Creek
activities.description: The Deer Creek trail is 7.6 miles long. It begins at Forest Road 582.1 and ends at Forest Road 956.2. The trail is open for the following uses: hiking, mountain biking, horseback riding. Hike through dense alpine forests along beautiful singletrack and enjoy the high alpine views that are available on this trail.

places.name: Chair Rocks
places.directions: Go 6.8 miles south of Conifer on US285 to Pine Valley Road (just a couple of miles past Schaffers Crossing) and turn left (southeast).  Thereâs a light and a turn lane at Pine Valley so itâs hard to miss.   Go about 10 miles to the town of Buffalo Creek.  Keep going just about another four miles and look for the Parking Lot on the right.

activities.name: Chair Rocks
activities.description: A mix between singletrack and doubletrack, this trail leads through a burn area left by the Buffalo Creek Fire in the '90s. The trail follows along a section of the Colorado Trail to Chair Rocks and an overlook of the South Platte area. The hike is very scenic. This trail is a multi-use trail so please watch out for mountain bike traffic, and practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Copper Triangle
places.directions: Take I-70 into the mountains and exit towards Copper Mountain. Park at any one of the number of parking lots in Copper Village.

activities.name: Copper Triangle
activities.description: Copper Triangle is about 30 miles of trail alternating between smooth singletrack and wide 4x4 road, double track, and paved roads. The trail quickly connects with the Colorado Trail on its climb up. Here you'll hike through thick, beautiful forests until you reach the tree line. Above the tree line you'll enjoy incredible views of the surrounding area.  This trail is a multi-use trail so please be on the lookout for mountain bikers.

places.name: Bear Creek/Methodist Mountain Loop
places.directions: This loop is a Salida mainstay. This trail has it all, a grueling gut-buster of a climb, sweet singletrack, a technical decent, and some pavement to round things out. The loop can begin/end at any number of locations. The following description starts in downtown Salida. However many people begin their journey at a pullout on CR 101 3.2 miles from US Hwy 50. By the way, the rainbow trail is dirt bike friendly so don't be shocked if you see a few.

activities.name: Bear Creek/Methodist Mountain Loop
activities.description: Right near town, the Bear Creek/Methodist Mountain Loop takes you up steep climbs, but rewards you with beautiful views of the Arkansas River Valley. After you make the brutal climb up there is a quick descent down a fireroad that leads you back into town. This trail meets up with the Rainbow Trail which helps to make it a loop.  This is a multi-use trail so please practice caution.

places.name: Round Mountain Foothills Nature Trail
places.directions: From Loveland, head west on 34.  Once you enter they canyon and pass under the huge water pipe, go for 3.8 miles and the Round Mountain trail head is on the south side of the road.

activities.name: Round Mountain Foothills Nature Trail
activities.description: As you stroll up the road to the overlook, you will discover Ponderosa Lane. The Ponderosa Pine is the most common tree in this area. In the plains below, few plants grow higher than the grasses and sagebrush, and spruces and firs take over in the Montane Life Zone at higher elevations.  To take this trail, there is a split in the main trail shortly after leaving the parking lot (about a 1/4 mile in) which allows you to continue on with the Foothills Nature Trail or instead go on to the summit of Sheep Mountain on the Round Mountain National Recreational Trail - Summit Adventure Trail portion, which is much more difficult and is rated as a Moderate difficulty level.

places.name: Dadd Gulch
places.directions: Take HWY 14 west from Fort Collins up Poudre Canyon for 29 miles from US 287 junction.  Trailhead on left.

activities.name: Dadd Gulch
activities.description: The trail follows a stream and an old stock trail up the gulch for about two miles before leaving the stream and passing through woods and meadows. A stock watering tank may be seen on the left just above the meadow. The upper portion of trail provides several panoramic vistas.  The trail ends at Salt Cabin Road, a forest road that loops north off Crown Point Road (forest road #139). This is a multiple use trail and is a favorite of mountain bikers and horseback riders as well as hikers and backpackers. Lower Dadd Gulch trailhead accommodates approximately 15 vehicles.

places.name: Michigan Ditch
places.directions: From Fort Collins Head North on 287 to HWY 14 (Teds Place) Go up HWY 14 for approximately 70 miles to the Cameron Pass Parking lot. Its right at the summit. On the right as you arrive from the east. Across the street you'll see a gate over a very well maintained road. This is the start of the trail.

activities.name: Michigan Ditch
activities.description: Michigan Ditch is a fairly flat loop trail that follows jeep roads and fire roads into the wilderness. As you hike along you'll get excellent views of the Never Summer Mountains in Rocky Mountain National Park, and the Nokhu Crags.  There are some steep drop-offs right beside the trail and there are bears and mountain lions in this area, so be careful!

places.name: Centennial Cone Park
places.directions: From Idaho Springs take I-70 east to Hwy.6 exit #244.east on Hwy 6 to Hwy 119 turn left [north] drive 1/2 mile to Douglas Mountain Road turn right it's about a mile to Centennial Cone Park. You can also take Hwy 6 west of Golden 11 miles to Hwy 119

activities.name: Centennial Cone Park
activities.description: Hike through the remains of many farms and homesteads in this Open Space Park. The trail takes you on top of the ridges above Clear Creek and offers beautiful views.  This is an incredibly scenic trail, and it's definitely a must-see if you're in the area. It is a multi-use trail so please practice caution.

places.name: Sheep Creek
places.directions: From Fairplay, CO, head south on 285 about five miles to Co Rd 5 heading west.  After about five miles on Co Rd 5, this road turns into Co Rd 22, take the right spur.  A half mile or so later, take Sheep Creek Trail (Co Rd 455) road on the right.   Follow this to forest Dr and go left.  The road ends at a parking lot for the trail.

activities.name: Sheep Creek
activities.description: Sheep Creek takes you through beautiful aspen groves and wide open fields that showcase the stunning mountains that surround you. There are some creek crossings along the trail and make sure to keep your eyes open for some beaver dams! This is a multi-use trail so be sure to share the path.

places.name: Sylvan Lake State Park
places.directions: To Sylvan Lake, Cabins & Campsites: Take I-70 to Eagle (Exit 147). Turn south and follow signs through town. Turn south on Brush Creek Road and travel 10 miles to the Visitor Center. Continue on Brush Creek Road until the road forks and becomes dirt. To reach the lake, at the fork, stay right and travel 5 miles to the campgrounds and cabins. To Brush Creek Yurts: Follow above directions until fork in road. Take left fork and travel 4 1/2 miles. The yurts are on left at the top of the switchbacks. The yurts are 9 1/2 miles from the lake.
places.description: Sylvan provides serenity in an alpine park perfect for daydreaming.  Non-motorized boating and non-electrical camping offer the opportunity for quiet recreation at this gateway to the White River National Forest and the Holy Cross Wilderness.

activities.name: Sylvan Lake State Park
activities.description: The 1.5 mile Lake Trail is open. New sections of the West Brush Creek Trail have been completed. Hike 1 mile downstream of the campground to check out Antones Creek and Borah Gulch. Or check out over 1.5 miles of new trail heading upstream from the Meadows Day Use Area. Popular trails on the surrounding White River National Forest - Sneve Gulch, McKenzie Gulch, Nolan Lake, Lake Charles and Ironedge are all good options.

places.name: Argentine Pass
places.directions: Take I70 west of Denver to Silver Plume exit turn left go under overpass turn right on dirt service road and park.

activities.name: Argentine Pass
activities.description: Argentine Pass' 21 miles lead over scenic singletrack, 4WD roads, a high alpine pass, and offer incredible mountain vistas. Along the hike you'll come upon the town of Waldorf, a ghost town now, which will take you back in time.  This is a multi-use trail so please practice caution.

places.name: Lily Lake
places.directions: Up the mountain south of Estes Park. A part of Rocky Mountain National Park

activities.name: Lily Lake
activities.description: Lily Lake Trail is a wide, easy graveled trail that circles Lily Lake. It is only 1 mile long and is perfect for strollers, wheelchairs, and people who aren't in the mood for a strenuous hike. If you want something a little more adventurous, add the Lily Ridge trail in, which branches off of the Lily Lake trail, climbs up along the ridge, and then drops back down to the lake. The Lily Mountain trail also starts nearby, for a true mountain hike.

places.name: Brockover Mesa - Outer Loop
places.directions: Four mile west of Pagosa Springs, turn north off highway 160 onto North Pagosa Blvd. Drive 3.7 miles. Look to your left opposite Mockingbird Place to see the forest entry gate #5.

activities.name: Brockover Mesa - Outer Loop
activities.description: Pass by ponds, forests, meadows, cattle fields, and creeks on the beautiful Brockover Mesa--Outer Loop Trail. The trail shifts between singletrack and logging roads, and provides stunning views in multiple spots. It's a great day hike to just enjoy the outdoors. This is a multi-use trail so please practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Dinosaur National Monument
places.directions: Located on the Colorado and Utah border, Dinosaur National Monument is within a one day drive from several major cities and other national park areas.Source: National Park Service

activities.name: Dinosaur National Monument
activities.description: Hiking in Dinosaur is an excellent way to appreciate the park's scenery and rugged landscape. The most popular trails begin near the visitor centers and the two paved tour roads. Other trails begin at more remote locations. There are 4 trails total, on the Colorado side of the park, with the trails ranging from 1/4 mile with wheel chair accessibility to 5 miles of rugged hiking.

places.name: Continental Divide Trail: Colorado
places.directions: Colorado

activities.name: Continental Divide Trail: Colorado
activities.description: The Continental Divide Trail is 3,100 miles long, stretching from Mexico to Canada and roughly following the continental divide. It is a part of the Triple Crown of long distance hiking trails in the US, along with the Pacific Crest Trail and Appalachian Trail. It is still under construction, so sections of it are constantly changing. The information posted here on Tripleblaze is the most up-to-date available, but these trail descriptions and GPS locations may become obsolete at some point in the future. If you notice any obsolete information, always feel free to post a review with the new info!  Whenever possible, the Google Maps location given for each section of trail will be for the most southern point. All sections are numbered in a south-to-north fashion.  The Colorado section runs for approximately 650 miles from the New Mexico border to the Wyoming border, traveling the high-altitude mountains through the wilds of the Colorado Rocky Mountains.  To follow the trail to the south, click on over to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3196/New-Mexico/Continental-Divide-Trail--New-Mexico.html">New Mexico section</a>. To follow the trail to the North, click on over to the <a href="http://www.tripleblaze.com/3/3203/Wyoming/Continental-Divide-Trail--Wyoming.html">Wyoming section</a>.

places.name: CDT CO41: Rabbit Ears Pass to Buffalo Pass
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO41: Rabbit Ears Pass to Buffalo Pass
activities.description: The CDT runs 15.3 miles from Rabbit Ears Pass near US Hwy 40 to Buffalo Pass. Along the way, the trail passes Dumont Lake and several other high-alpine lakes. The Mountain View trail spurs off of this trail, and it offers some gorgeous views of the surrounding mountains and down into the valley with Steamboat Springs below. Much of this section of the CDT trail runs through gorgeous high-alpine meadows, which are just full of beautiful wild flowers!

places.name: Paradox Trail
places.directions: Many places to jump on the trail in the towns of Naturita, Bedrock, and Paradox. Access also available at Buckeye Reservoir near the Utah border.

activities.name: Paradox Trail
activities.description: The Paradox Trail links the Tabeguache Trail on the Uncompahgre Plateau with the Kokopelli Trail in the La Sal Mountains of Utah.  The 100-mile trail traverses a wide variety of terrain, elevation, and eco-zones, following existing jeep and county roads for most of its length. The adventurous nature of the Paradox Trail requires users to be cautious, personally responsible, self-sufficient, and have a working knowledge of backcountry survival.

places.name: Yampa River State Park
places.directions: Yampa River State Park offers several public access sites along a 134-mile stretch of the Yampa River between Hayden and the Dinosaur National Monument near the Utah border. The central park office is located on Highway 40 between the cities of Craig and Hayden. See the Yampa River State Park Brochure and Map for locations of all public access sites.
places.description: Yampa River State Park, located in the beautiful Yampa valley west of Steamboat Springs, is actually three "parks" in one.

activities.name: Yampa River State Park
activities.description: At the Headquarters Campground, walkers can enjoy a mile of nature trail to work the kinks out from the long day's drive. The primary hiking opportunity is at many of the river access sites along the river. Hiking in the area is primarily on BLM lands and offers a diverse experience for all levels and interests. With the high-desert environment, your hikes can offer some of the most scenic views found anywhere. Areas like Duffy Mt., Juniper Canyon and Cross Mountain have some excellent hiking territory.

places.name: CDT CO11: Carson Saddle Trailhead to Spring Creek Pass Trailhead
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO11: Carson Saddle Trailhead to Spring Creek Pass Trailhead
activities.description: The CDT runs with the Colorado Trail for 17.1 miles from the Carson Saddle Trailhead to the Spring Creek Pass Trailhead at Hwy 149. Along the way, the trail passes the highpoint of the Colorado Trail, Pt. 71 Mountain, and Jarosa Mesa.

places.name: Palmer Park
places.directions: From Academy Blvd. (heading south) turn right on Maizeland Rd.  An entrance to the park is on the right just past the ballfields also on the right.  Palmer Park is almost right in the middle of town (north of the airport, south of Chapel Hills Mall).

activities.name: Palmer Park
activities.description: Great hiking trails for all skill levels. The park topography consists of a mesa with finger-like extensions dotted with pine and scrub. Great views of the city and miles of trails!

places.name: Seven Bridges Trail
places.directions: Head up Gold Camp road to the High-Drive Rd./Captain Jack's trailhead.  Follow Gold Camp {closed to vehicles} till you get to Cheyenne Creek.  On the right side of the creek is the trail which leads up either to the Buckhorn cut-off trail on the left, or Seven Bridges on the right.

activities.name: Seven Bridges Trail
activities.description: The trailhead is directly off the closed portion of Gold Camp Rd. (on the west side). Park at the intersection of Gold Camp Rd, High Dr. and Cheyenne Cañon Rd. Hike past the gate, which is in the northwest corner of the parking area, and follow the closed portion of Gold Camp Rd .7 miles to the trailhead. The trail is unmarked, so you will need to watch for the creek that goes under the road, and the trailhead will be on your right. This is a moderate hike, which criss-crosses Cheyenne Creek over a series of seven bridges.

places.name: Lower Loop
places.directions: You can connect to this trail directly from Crested Butte Via Butte Avenue and Peanut Lake Road. On the other end, you can park just off the bottom of the Gunsight Pass Road which splits off of the Slate River Road.

activities.name: Lower Loop
activities.description: This is an easy hiking trail that is accessible right from the residential streets of Crested Butte. These trails are relatively flat, but the lack of trees allows them to provide incredible views of the surrounding mountain peaks and the nearby Slate River. This is very popular with locals and tourists alike.

places.name: Doudy Draw Trail
places.directions: From Boulder, take CO-93 S to Hwy 170 (Eldorado Springs exit).  Turn right and drive about 1.8 miles.  The trailhead will be on your right.

activities.name: Doudy Draw Trail
activities.description: Doudy Draw Trail is a 4 mile hiking trail in Eldorado Springs, Colorado.

places.name: Meadow View
places.directions: Elk Meadow trail head

activities.name: Meadow View
activities.description: 3 mile hiking trail located near Evergreen, Colorado

places.name: 3 Sisters / Alderfer
places.directions: From I-70, take CO 74/Evergreen Pkwy to downtown Evergreen.  Turn right onto County Rd. 73 and go about a mile to Buffalo Park Rd.  Follow the signs to the parking area on the right.

activities.name: 3 Sisters / Alderfer
activities.description: Near the heart of Evergreen, Alderfer/Three Sisters Park abounds with stunning vistas, landmark rock formations, beautiful old stands of ponderosa pine and the most trails per acre of any foothills park-nearly 15 miles on 770 acres. Open meadows, forests, and great views are all around.

places.name: San Luis State Park
places.directions: Take Highway 160 west from Walsenburg for 60 miles just past the town of Blanca. Go north on Highway 150 for 13.5 miles. Turn left on Six Mile Lane and drive straight for 8 miles and then drive north 1/8 mile to park entrance.
places.description: In the shadow of the Great Sand Dunes National Park is peaceful San Luis State Park and Wildlife Area. Waterfowl, shorebirds, songbirds and raptors fill the sky over this unique desert ecosystem, making San Luis an outstanding watchable wildlife area most of the year.

activities.name: San Luis State Park
activities.description: Four miles of wide, level gravel trails in the wildlife area provide a pleasant, safe hiking or mountain biking experience among the low dunes and wetlands. The wildlife area is closed from Feb. 15 until July 15 annually.

places.name: Estes Cone
places.directions: 1: N40 16.330	 W105 33.409 - 0.0 miles : Longs Peak Trailhead2: N40 16.495	 W105 33.852 - .45 miles : Estes Cone Trail spli3: N40 17.716	 W105 34.04 - 3.05 miles : Estes Cone

activities.name: Estes Cone
activities.description: Estes Cone is located 3.05 miles from the Longs Peak Trailhead on the east side of Rocky Mountain National Park. A short but steep climb up this conical formation rewards hikers with panoramic views of Longs Peak, the Continental Divide, and Estes Park area:   The trail climbs steadily in a mixed pine forest to the Chasm Lake - Estes Cone Trail split and turns sharply north (.45 miles : 9,670'). It continues on a moderate grade that levels over a stream (1.3 miles) to the Eugenia Mine site - a settler era gold mine which in the words of the Park "produced more dreams than gold".   The trail dips past the mine to Moore Park Backcountry Campsite (1.6 miles : 9,732') and begins a steep push to the summit, covering almost 1,000' in the final .7 miles.   Cairns help identify the trail, but can be difficult to spot, especially with lingering snow. A 20 yard scramble up steep scree leads to the bare-rock summit of Estes Cone (3.05 miles : 11,002').

places.name: Maxwell Falls
places.directions: From Evergreen drive south on  Hwy 73 right at Brook Forest Road for three miles.

activities.name: Maxwell Falls
activities.description: One of the easiest trails in the district, Maxwell Falls is a very enjoyable hike. It follows Maxwell Creek, and the waterfalls are at their best in the spring when the snow runoff is plentiful. Jefferson County law requires dogs be on a leash at all times while on this trail.

places.name: Trinidad Lake State Park
places.directions: Heading north on I-25, take Exit 13B to West Main Street. At the first four-way stop, turn left onto Nevada. At the next four-way stop by the Welcome Center, turn left and continue west on Highway 12 for 3.5 miles. Heading south on I-25, take exit 13B and at the stop sign, turn left under the freeway towards town. At the four-way stop next to the Sonic, go left on Nevada and make a left at the next four-way stop. Take Hwy 12 west for 3.5 miles.
places.description: Trinidad Lake is a wonderful place to escape the crowds and establish a basecamp from which to explore the great outdoors.

activities.name: Trinidad Lake State Park
activities.description: There's so much to see on Trinidad's trails! Ten miles of trails reward eager explorers wanting to learn, exercise or conduct nature study. Several trails are ADA-accessible. Sights range from open vistas, to grasslands, forests, cliffs and ponds. Cold-weather enthusiasts can enjoy hiking all winter.

places.name: CDT CO20: Hancock to Garden Basin
places.directions: CO

activities.name: CDT CO20: Hancock to Garden Basin
activities.description: The 20th section of the Continental Divide Trail in Colorado runs for 14.2 miles from the Hancock Trailhead to the Garden Basin Trailhead. Along the way, the trail passes Tincup Pass, Tincup Peak, Mirror Lake, Mirror Lake Campground, Mount Poor, Fitzpatrick Peak, and Emma Burr Mountain.

places.name: Hermosa Creek Trail
places.directions: From Durango Drive north on Hwy 550 towards Purgatory ski resort. Drive past the resort and make the first left, road FS 578 or San Juan CR 38. Follow that road up and make a right at the T on top. Take the next right and follow the dirt road down the valley. Follow the signs for Sig Creek Campground and Hermosa Creek Trailhead. The campground and parking lot are on the South side of the road and require a short river crossing, usually it's shallow, but it's a good idea to check.

activities.name: Hermosa Creek Trail
activities.description: Hike among high ridges and deep canyons along this remote trail. The trail is wide, well-maintained, and very easy to hike, and it winds through beautiful forests, open meadows with views of the La Platas, and fields of wildflowers.  The main trail is about 16 miles, but there are plenty of side trails to explore. Either day hike or spend a couple days backpacking and exploring this area!

places.name: Fox Run Regional Park
places.directions: Located at the Northern edge of Colorado Springs.  Take the Baptist Road exit, East from I-25.  Drive north a couple miles to the T-intersection and take a right on Roller Coaster road.   There will be a parking area a couple hundred yards down the road, to the right.

activities.name: Fox Run Regional Park
activities.description: Fox Run Park is located in the Black Forest approximately three miles east of Interstate 25. The 417-acre park features spectacular views of Pikes Peak, four miles of trails, multi-use fields, two playgrounds, two ponds, and five picnic pavilions. There are 2 looped trails that weave throughout the ponderosa forests. This is a multi-use trail so please share the path with mountain bikers.

places.name: Waterton Canyon
places.directions: From Denver, take 470 west towards littleton.  Exit at Wadsworth Blvd (CO 121).  Go about 4 miles and follow the signs to the park.  Park in the lot on the left.  The trail starts on the opposite side of the road.

activities.name: Waterton Canyon
activities.description: Strontia Springs Dam is six and one-half miles upstream of the mouth of Waterton Canyon on the South Platte River. Water is diverted from the reservoir into a 3.4 mile-long tunnel under the mountains to the Foothills Water Treatment Plant. Completed in 1983, this dam towers 243 feet above the South Platte streambed, forming a 1.7 mile-long lake with 98 surface acres.

places.name: Eagle Trail
places.directions: From HWY 50 in Grand Jct, take HWY 340 across the Colorado River.  Take a left on Monument Road and after 2 miles the parking area will be on the left.

activities.name: Eagle
activities.description: Hike along rocky ledges on this 2 mile out-and-back hike. Enjoy stunning views of the surrounding desert cliffs and mesas. The entire hike is pretty rocky, so watch your step. This is a multi-use trail, so please practice trail etiquette.

places.name: Zion Curtain
places.directions: From Fruita traveling west on the I-70 exit at the Rabbit Valley 2 exit. Go right and follow the dirt road north up and over the hill then west to parking area.  Begin on this 2 track going west to the I-70 underpass approx. 3 miles to I-70 underpass. Proceed south under the Interstate and about a half mile or so take the first singletrack on your left.

activities.name: Zion Curtain
activities.description: Zion Curtain is a 12 mile loop trail near Fruita, CO. This dusty trail will give you a good workout as you climb up to the top of the rim. From there you'll hike along the top for most of the time and you'll get to take in the beautiful desert scenery.  This is a multi-use trail, so please share the path.

places.name: Saxon Mountain
places.directions: Take I-70 west of Denver to Georgetown exit #228 Drive under the overpases and park at the Visitors Center on the right

activities.name: Saxon Mountain
activities.description: Saxon Mountain trail is a rocky and steep path that climbs 2500ft up to the top of Saxon Mountain where you'll hit 11,050ft in elevation. From the top you'll get an amazing view of Mt. Evans and the Divide.  This is a multi-use trail so please share the path!

places.name: State Forest State Park
places.directions: I-70 to the Empire exit, Highway 40, over Berthoud Pass through Winter Park and Granby. 2 miles west of Granby take Highway 125 45 miles to the east side of Rand. Take County Road 27 14 miles to Highway 14, go right to the park 3 miles. Or I-25 to Cheyenne, WY. Take I-80 to Laramie 45 miles. Take Highway 230 to Walden 60 miles then take Highway 14 east to the park 25 miles. Or if Highway 287 is open take it to Laramie and out of Laramie take Highway 230 to Walden 60 miles and then Highway 14 east 25 miles to the park.
places.description: The ultimate in rugged Colorado, State Forest State Park offers visitors 71,000 acres of forest, jagged peaks, alpine lakes, wildlife and miles of trails.  The park stretches along the west side of the Medicine Bow Mountains and into the north end of the Never Summer Range.

activities.name: State Forest State Park
activities.description: The ultimate in rugged Colorado, State Forest State Park offers visitors 71,000 acres of forest, jagged peaks, alpine lakes, wildlife and miles of trails. The park stretches along the west side of the Medicine Bow Mountains and into the north end of the Never Summer Range.   There are plenty of trails that wind through this beautiful park, ranging from .8 miles to 8 miles (one way). There's something for everyone, from the families with small children to the avid backcountry hiker.

places.name: Vega State Park
places.directions: Take exit 49 (if coming from Grand Junction) off I-70 to HWY 65, go approximately 18 miles on Hwy 65 and turn left onto HWY 330. Go 12 miles to the town of Collbran. Stay on 330 East past Collbran for about 12 miles to Mesa County Rd. 64 6/10ths Rd. and turn right at the "Vega State Park" sign. Go 5 miles to the Park Entrance Station, and go another half mile and turn right across Vega Dam to the Park Visitor Center. If coming from Denver, take Exit 62 off of I-70 turn left and follow 45 1/2 Road approximately 12 miles to Hwy 65 and turn left, proceed 1/4 mile and turn left onto Hwy 330 and follow this road as directed above to the park.
places.description: At an elevation of 8,000 feet, Vega State Park's high-mountain lake sits in a beautiful montane meadow on the western edge of Grand Mesa National Forest in Western Colorado.

activities.name: Vega State Park
activities.description: Hikers can enjoy easy wildflower walks between Oak Point and Island campgrounds or along the South Road and near the Meadows Group Shelter Area. For a more strenuous two-mile natural surface trail through aspen forest and mountain shrub vegetation begin at the OHV parking lot. This trail doubles as a snowshoe trail in winter months.
